39186108.review:
I wanted to like it but it is more about managing annoyance then negotiating obstacles.

Healing is a complete pain, requiring some time, but monsters spawn regularly even in areas you just cleared.  Equipment has lots of hassles, from low carrrying capacity, to cursed things which nearly all classes can't detect.  They're frequently dropped, can't be removed, and rarely fall off.  However nearly all classes can't unlock doors so if you try to kick one open your new magic plate armor may be destroyed by the trap you set off, even if you searched that square 5 times before you kicked in the door. 

You can hardly find shops anywhere to dump your loot, and crappy options to buy.  Also too many annoyances like so many different types of arrows or quarrels (among 6 or so different missile types with their own skill), that you then have to pick up each time you shoot one and re-equip once each small pile runs out.  

Lots of creativity in the game, but takes "rogue-like" principle of avoid mistakes and just turns it into "manage craptastic shitstorm."

39108524.review:
I am writing this in response to a thoughtful but negative review by Euplatious - I tried to comment on his/her review, but this rambling mess I wrote blows the comment character length so now it shall be a review itself!

Also, note that I have minimal time in ADOM logged in Steam but I played it on and off for 3 years back before it was on Steam and beat it.  I mainly bought the Steam version to support the brilliant Developer!  I never sent him his postcard and for that I feel guilty - so I bought it instead, he certainly deserves the money.

So - 

Roguelikes like ADOM aren't necessarily about being 'fair' but instead are about risk management, survival, and learning.  Do I recommend ADOM?  Hell yes!

Some very minor spoilers exist below, plus a rambling anecedote about a real life survival training exercise - so, fair warning...

I remember one of the first times I played ADOM I kicked a staircase in a dungeon and the whole dang thing fell down on my head, killing my pretty successful character who had gone further than other runs up to that time!  I was like, what the hell was that?!?  I looked it up and it is a known thing that happens rarely.  Apparently if you kick stairs you can get a bonus (I think it builds strength?  It has been awhile), but occasionally it will kill you dead.  It is rare that kicking stairs will kill you - but it happened to me on the first try so I guess I won the anti-lottery.  

I quit ADOM for a few weeks in disgust, then went back and avoided kicking stairs :).  Eventually (after 3 years of on and off effort) I beat the game (Elven Archer) for the normal win (closing the chaos gate) and had low enough chaos I got a  good ending too.   This was all on an older ASCII version, not the Steam version.  I actually took my wife out to dinner and had a nice bottle of champagne to celebrate - few games actually make you feel like you achieved something for real, but I felt like I had done so when I beat ADOM!

So personally I rate ADOM as one of the greatest games I have ever played.  Don't let occasional unfairness deter you from playing it.  Swear a lot when you die, have a break, and try again when you are ready.

Fun fact - I later did a survival training walk in the Pilbara in Australia's outback - it was a five day hike starting out intot the wild with only two litres of water and a full belly (plus a basic survival kit and one of those lightweight survival blankets).  I wasn't alone (5 other students plus two instructors) but it was as close to a real emergency as could be 'safely' simulated - we had to find and purify our own water, improvise any tool besides our survival knives, forage for what food we could (or starve, we did a fair bit of that :), make our own shelter and fire, navigate for ourselves etc (we did have a somewhat out of date and high level map of the general area), and on the last day our instructors kindly abandoned us (they did give us a walkie-talkie in case something really went wrong :) and we had to reach the finish line without even their comforting advice (thats what they were there for really, to advise us, and teach us a last few things that you have to be in the field to learn, and also to maybe save our butts if we got bitten by a snake, but not to do the work for us - it was survival training!).  

Anyway, the point of this rambling story - at times on that walk, I found myself feeling like I was playing ADOM :).  It was all about resource management, cautious risk taking, maintaining what control you could - more over yourself than anything else really - and thus staying calm and clear thinking, preserving your health and wellbeing, and not giving up, no matter what.  It was tough, but man was it (masochistically) fun (and who woulda thunk you can find a pebbly pile of rocks as soft as a featherbed after 4 days of survival hiking.  Wow!)

But there you go - Roguelikes like ADOM can actually teach you some aspects of survival thinking. Now that's potentially handy!  

So if you have no other survival skills, but find yourself in a survival situation, try to think like you are playing a hardcore roguelike is my advice (but you know, if you die, you don't get to try again, so be extra roguelike!).  

So go play ADOM!

38586448.review: Let me summarize by saying  I love ADOM but am not sure if it's for you, I 'll explain. No game has ever had me fist pump, yell with glee, scream in terror, or pout with discouragement as this game. That's what makes it great, it's a game that inspires very strong emotions, and that's why I love it. Upsides are there are tons of artifacts I've only seen once then never again, or not at all, making exploration very exciting, you never know if you'll find some new epic gear you've never seen before each playthrough. Now the downside, this is a roguelike, you expect it to be hard. You want it to be hard. You want to lose a character you loved, come back and kill that SOB with your next guy with flaming fires of avenging RAGE! That you can do, and it feels great, but early game is really, really tough. Specifically there are creatures which with one hit can poison you, stun you, confuse, or paralyse you, any of these status affects almost always end up in instant deaths. And first times through you won't know, hey don't get close to that guy or you'll die, in 1 hit. You're just hitting everything else like normal then pop, game over. The game guides I have found are terrible at explaining hey if you see this type of creature stay away, there's no list like that anywhere I have found. I learned by trial and error which was extremely frustrating. But once you get past that nonsense, the middle and late game is fantastic with enourmous depth. Artstyle and music are also wonderful. If you like rouguelikes this is one you definetly should buy, no question, just know what you're getting into.

38443407.review:
Hi,

I first played the game back in Grade 10, back in 2004 (13 years ago) and thoroughly enjoyed the ASCII game back then. So, imagine my surprise when it got a successful launch of Indiegogo; I'd have joined onto that investment opportunity, but well, ADOM had faded from my mind by that point and wasn't actually looking for it. However, these days, I'm happy I didn't get on it, as I throughly regret purchasing ADOM Deluxe. 

When I first bought ADOM Deluxe, it had like 50% of the promised features on day one. Then, the developer went on a very long hiatus, holding up the development team, and we had no content updates for over a year and a half. I gave up on the game, sometime around June of 2017, of ever seeing an actual update to ADOM. Fast forward 6 months, and I found out that ADOM finally got a slew of major updates. So, I redownloaded the game to try it out.

Honestly, I should have just left ADOM on steam collecting dust. The interface changes are terrible; hell in the character creation screen, most of the text pops out of the interface boxes... a sign that things weren't going to be good. Created a new character, and most of the controls I've learned to use from the old ASCII build and the build I played back in Dec of 2016, are all changed. The interface and controls has been changed and not for the better. Being that the game forces you to know a ton of information, just to make it playable, forcing players to relearn a brand new interface and keybindings is too much.

Honestly, I'd suggest everyone to stick to the free, ASCII build. It was a pretty good game then, and it is now too, but you have to really dig to find it, and these days I have better things to do that relearn everything from scratch. If you want to support Thomas, then buy the game. But, if you want to play the game, don't bother with the Deluxe edition.

I'd stick around and offer advice on how to fix things, but honestly, the last time I tried to do that, the toxic community and the hostile development team, ate me alive. And watch, as they do so again!

tl;dr = Excellent game, just don't bother with the Deluxe edition; its just not worth it.

Pra quem gosta de Roguelikes, ADOM é uma excelente pedida.

O jogo tem uma certa variedade de modos prontos (história, hardcore, challenge of the week, etc) que conseguem englobar diversos perfis de jogadores, mas se você não se encaixar em nenhum desses, também é possível customizar o seu jogo do jeitinho que você quiser. 

Os desenvolvedores têm lançado atualizações regularmente que melhoram cada vez mais a interface e a jogabilidade com o mouse, e facilitam o aprendizado dos jogadores novos (eu me incluo nessa).

Prepare-se para morrer muito durante suas aventuras, porque esse jogo realmente não perdoa! O positivo é que, a cada morte, você aprende algo novo e fica mais preparado para as próximas tentativas.

Uma boa dica é jogar com a Wiki do jogo aberta no celular ou algo do tipo, porque assim você conseguirá ter uma base melhor para não se perder dentro de ADOM.

 Se você está na dúvida se ADOM é para você ou não, eles têm uma versão gratuita disponível para download no site oficial do jogo. Essa versão não oferece toda a customização da versão da Steam, e costuma demorar bastante para ser atualizada, mas com ela dá para ter uma melhor noção do que é o jogo e saber se é o seu tipo de jogo ou não.

38391134.review:
I really enjoy classic Roguelike games, and have played everything from Rogue proper to Moria, Angband, Nethack, Zangband, Cthband, TOME, and more.  I though that ADOM would be another success in that line of games that I would really embrace, and was really looking forward to playing it.  

And there are a lot of things that ADOM does well, such as a better graphics presentation than anything else not-named TOME or some character building options and decisions.  You also have the major keys you want to press that bring up various screens on the side of the UI so you can use hotkeys like every Roguelike player has had to do or you can just click and play that way.  Good job on those, ADOM!

I also enjoy the additions of leveling up with skills, training, the sign you were born under, and more, and the character design has more teeth to it than a lot of other games in the genre.  

There are a few qualms that I have though.  Most Roguelikes are hard, that's the point.  They are designed to be a challenge, and no less so with ADOM, especially in the early game. I give ADOM mad props for being tough too.  But where it errs is pushing that to design decisons that make the game require extensive foreknowledge or heavy subsequent plays to have a shot at winning.  I'll give you two examples of that in a moment.  But that is not a normal Roguelike tactic. I can pick up, and win at, Angband without reading the entire wikia first and five or six walkthroughs and watching YouTube videos.  Sure, I will get better as I play more, which is true of other games, but Angband and friends always played fair with you, even when it was playing hard.  I won Angband without scumming.  I never came close to beating Moria.  I almost beat Zangband, but lost in the final battle.  You get the idea.    


ADOM doesn't play fair.  It has design decisions that force you to know about ahead of time and plan for. 

Here are two examples, one early, and one later:

Early Example - In the first town, there are two mutually exclusive quests that you could come across by talking with one of two people there, and the first one you talk to gives that quest.  Since you have a quest coming into that town to talk to as many people in the first town as you can, you are talking to them anyways, as there is an in-game incentive to complete that quest.  But one of two quests gives you a prize thats good for some characters and not others, and vice versa.  I took the wrong quest becuase I didn't know that the town had two quests that are mutually exclusive, and they don't even need to be.  Both create seperate dungeons and characters, and you certainly could do them both.  Without knowing the rewards ahead of time, you miss out on a major quest reward early.  


Middle Game Example - There is a dungeon in the game called the pyramid that you cannot get to until you're of a high enough level.  I entered it when I arrived in the vicinity with my Halfling Duelist and was told I didn't have an invite.  Then around level 14 I found a papyrus and read it, and I was invited for a challenge at the pyramid. Now's that's totally fine up until now.  You have dungeons that open up later pretty often in lots of RPGs, including Roguelikes such as Zangband.  I finished my dungeon delve of this 12 level dungon and then by the time I had finished I had reached level 17, and then I stepped out, dropped off some of my extra gear at this oasis I found, and then went to the pyramid.  But I couldn't enter it.  Why not?  I still had the papyrus with me.  So I looked it up on the Wikia.  And this is a major and very important dungeon to complete because the ruler has two major guaranteed artifacts you really want to snag.  And the issue was that you can only enter it from levels 13-16.  I was too high to do that challenge.  I saw that one of the items, a special armor, is one that is perfect for my class, and really helps you survive long term, and I missed out.  

That's ADOM.  Design decisions have been made about the game but have not been communicated to you as a player.  The papyrus that invited me to the pyramid didn't say that I couldn't arrive after level 16 and it was a limited time offer.  The quest in the first city never said that if I accepted it I couldn't do another quest instead.  

So the result is a game that appears, with the investment of a few hours, to be a sturdy entry into the Roguelike genre, but the more I delve into it, the more I realize that this is not a game that plays fair with me as a player.  And why would I want to continue to play that sort of game after already investing more than 20 hours into it? 

This could have been a game I would easily have seen myself with 100+ hours.  But there are these horrible design choices that don't respect me as a player or give me the agency to change them in the game.  That's a major philosophical issue that I hope the game cleans up.  And if it does, and becomes more player friendly with inforamtion in the game, or changing up some of those design decisions, then I would certianly be open to revisiting this review and the game itself.  But that's not today.  And it's likely not tomorrow either.  


It's okay to be hard.  It's not okay to hide information that makes the game harder.
38391134.developer_response:
Thanks for the extensive comments.

I agree with you (somewhat) on the pyramid issue - there could be a hint about this being a timed quest that only is available for a limited amount of time. Please note two things though: (a) It is highly unlikely that you will win the game on a streak that first gets you to the pyramid - so normally you'll not lose anything as you will have learned about the time limit after one game. (b) While the rewards are very good they are still not required in any way to win. So it's not like you are truly losing something important.

Nonetheless I get your point and have added an RFE to address this issue in one of the next releases: http://www.adom.de/forums/project.php?issueid=5863

I personally disagree about your comments on the mututally exclusive quests in the village... as neither of it is truly important for solving the game and there are so many different venues you can take in the beginning that it IMHO just doesn't matter. BTW the (a) argument from above also applies here: Probabilities are basically zero that you are going to win on your first, second or third game - so by the time you have learned enough you'll know about the exclusivity.

The design philosophy behind this is basically that choices matter - being able to do everything at any time is quite easy for the player, but I prefer forcing you to make difficult choices. That's also why I agree about the pyramid point because you (1) don't even get to know abut being forced to make a choice and (2) the rewards are a lot more important than the ones in the village choice.

In summary: Thanks for your feedback and sorry for you not being able to enjoy ADOM as much as you should due to my conscious choices. 

Merry Christmas nonetheless!

I've been playing ADOM for 15 years, and I still love it. One of my favorite roguelikes. 38388975.review:
ADOM is the truest roguelike there is. It feels like playing a solo game of Dungeons & Dragons with a supercomputer as a DM. There's a lot of room to be clever in every situation, but at the same time, you live and die by the whims of fate. This review assumes you're OK with that, as it's a basic premise of all roguelikes. If you aren't sure, you can download a free version of the game from their site and try it out.

+ [b]Unparalleled depth[/b] - tons of strategies, treasures, and interactions to discover
+ [b]Challenging turn-based combat[/b] - it might take dying once or twice, but the game teaches you how best to survive
+ [b]Aesthetically honed[/b] - graphics, animations, and sounds are lovingly made and engrossing, while the story and NPC dialogue keeps you feeling like your heroism is meaningful
+ [b]Ongoing development[/b] - the stuff being added to the game is actually outpacing the rate I can discover it

- [b]Steep learning curve[/b] - lots of keybindings combined with a "learn by dying" approach can be offputting to new players
- [b]Very hard to win[/b] - I've won twice in four years of playing. I have a level 49 wizard on track for a special "ultra ending", but can't work up the courage to actually take the plunge with him yet, which leads me to...
- [b]Demands constant vigilance[/b] - one mistaken keypress or unnoticed enemy can cost you a character, which can be stressful
- [b]Rare crashes[/b] - these used to kill your character, but now the game saves frequent backups for you, so it's hardly a setback

ADOM's a pretty incredible game that can pull you back even after it kills your luckiest character. Don't let the equal-sized pro/con list fool you - I wholeheartedly recommend this game. It's seriously one of a kind.

38386431.review:
Cóż mogę napisać. 

Najlepszy rogalik w klimacie D&D jaki miałem możliwość grania. Wracam do tej gry dość regularnie i nigdy mi sie nie nudzi. 

Każdy tu znajdzie sobie ulubioną kombinację rasy i klasy oraz ścieżkę rozwoju. (tak tu można zostać szczurzym złodziejem który ma aspiracje na miano boga chaosu lub po prostu zwykłym wojownikiem bohaterem który poczuł powołanie aby zamknąć bramę chaosu)

Potężnie rozbudowana mechanika gry oraz jej losowość gry sprawia, że ta gra potrafi zaskoczyć nawet po dekadzie grania w nią od czasu do czasu.

Turowy system gry oraz klimatyczna muzyka pozwala odprężyć się po stresującym dniu pracy.

Co ciekawe gra jest nadal prężnie rozwijana pomimo tego, że powstała pierwotnie na DOS i amigę.

37847400.review:
ADOM has been in development since 1994, and wow do you feel it. The idea of a title with complex, emergent gameplay with an evident and long history of development gave me strong Dwarf Fortress vibes.
    ADOM is probably one of the more Rogue-like roguelikes you can find on Steam. The game is stuffed with content, including dozens and dozens of ways to meet your demise. If you survive, the game promises many rewards. You can become a king, or achieve godhood. Neither of which I experienced, because in my few hours of the game I simply stumbled into various ways to die within 24 hours.
    I had mild frustrations with the controls and UI. Usually the mouse would be sufficient to navigate and find the information I wanted, but sometimes I would find myself confused on why a spell didn't fire correctly or how to perform certain actions. Understandable considering it's history, but that doesn't mean I'm still not a spoiled modern gamer. Evidently the game will be getting an updated rerelease sometime soon, which I expect will resolve some user unfriendliness.
    I'd highly recommend this game if you're deep into roguelikes, difficult games, or imaginative adventures. I'd also recommend this title if you missed out on 90s PC gaming and want a little taste of history.

В последнее время люди стали забывать, что такое рогалик. Рогалик это не экшн, скилл и пострелушки на пиу-пиу лазерах. Рогалики - это испытание на сосредоточенность, мозги и холодный расчет. Рогалики, это когда механика игры позволяет случится самым невероятным вещам, которые ты будешь помнить еще долго. Во всяких новомодных реалтаймовых рогаликах каждый отдельный забег отличается от другого только компановкой уровней и лутом. Но в этой игре каждый отдельный забег это отдельная история, со взлетами и падениями. Недавно умер мой тролл-паладин 7 уровня. Этот один тролл-паладин запоминился мне больше, чем все остальные реалтаймы вместе взятые.
В общем, достойная переделка старой игры.

37236549.review:
I've been playing ADOM for some time now - long before it was available on steam. I love the game, but it is bloody merciless. This game will kill you for making a single mistake, it can kill you due to a single poorly timed attack, you can die from pure bad-luck. Heck, the game slowly kills you _just for playing_. And this is a rouge-like game. Once you die, that's it - character's gone.

Of course, this is how it's supposed to be. This game is designed for the kind of person who will not be stopped by repeated failures. Someone meticulous enough to painstakingly construct a winning strategy and execute it perfectly... Or you can do what I do: use the cheats that come along with the steam version to disable corruption and allow reload on death. :)

Thomas Biskup has delivered an extremely deep and engaging experience, polished over years. Highly recommended.

36995865.review:
Вот ни фига это не рогалик. Вот вообще не рогалик. Это полноценная ролевая игра, со сложным сюжетом, выбором стиля поведения, принятием решений. От рогалика тут всего две вещи - ASCII-графика (после долгих лет, проведенных в текстовом режиме, я так и не смог привыкнуть к этим дурацким тайлам) и беспощадность к персонажу (умирающему каждый раз с концами[spoiler], что впрочем можно решить при помощи wand of save/load[/spoiler]). Зато все остальное затыкает за пояс большинство современных "ролевых игр", разработчики которых считают, что наличие дерева прокачки автоматически позволяет ставить этот тэг.

Проработка деталей также на высоте. В какой еще игре будут команды типа "прочистить уши" или "вытереть лицо", которые при этом реально могут понадобиться? Когда я при первых прохождениях дошел до [spoiler]баньши, я неделю искал возможности замочить ее издалека, не входя в радиус действия ее смертельного вопля. Только потом до меня дошло, что  вроде бы совершенно бесполезный воск из улья вполне может помочь[/spoiler]. Или чего стоит вполне возможная ситуация, когда [spoiler]персонажа приносят в жертву темному божеству, если он случайно наступил на алтарь[/spoiler]. Да даже чего далеко ходить. Влияние оказывает даже календарная дата, когда была начата игра. Даже в нерандомизированной части игры всегда находится что-то пропущенное в предыдущих прохождениях. Игра вообще поражает нюансами глубинной логики типа влияния первого убитого за игру монстра на глубину залегания необходимого для прохождения артефакта.

ADoM как HL, игроки в который делятся на тех, кто не доехал на трамвае, и тех, кто прошел игру несколько сотен раз. Игроки в ADoM делятся на слабаков, бросивших играть после первых смертей персонажа в первом же данжоне, и тех, кто давно обосновался в храме с жуками, доступном после первой сотни игровых смертей

Появлению в стиме предшествовали долгие годы разработки силами одного человека, и от версии к версии появлялись новые возможности, новые квесты, новые локации, новые персонажи. Автор утверждает, что финальной версии игры не будет никогда, и я склонен ему верить.

36600165.review: I played a little of ADOM before the resurrection. It's one of the big names that really paved the way for the roguelike genre. ADOM is fairly unique among the other big traditional roguelikes. It's a lot more about story, not satisfied just with fun mechanics under a vague fantasy theme. The presence of the overworld and the interactivity of NPCs offering quests really elevates the RPG elements and immerses the player into the world. Since development was resurrected, the work done has been incredible in taking an already complete experience and modernizing the game, fixing bugs and adding content. The tiles and overall graphics are some of the best among traditional roguelikes (although there are a few menus that still look like an emulated terminal), and the soundtrack is one of my favorites in video games. A lot of work has been put into making the game far more accessible to new players, along with the introduction of more forgiving modes where you can customize the experience or simply play without permadeath.

It might run well on ciurrent hardware (fonts scale great and look smashigly sharp at 4K!) but make no mistake the engine behind it is purge old-school rouge-like. 36118828.developer_response:
Ok, it seems that my past comment with actual content was deleted? I didn't even know that you could do that. Which leaves my snarky remark as the only remaining comment from me and shifts the picture more negatively than it IMHO originally appeared.

To repeat the factual points I raised in my now deleted comment:
- It seems that the review does not relate to the most recent release but an older version as many aspects (like tedious keymapping, missing hints and guidance) have been addressed. As we try very hard to improve the game based on feedback I advised the reviewer to once more try out the latest release and see if it felt improved for him.
- I commented on being expensive with the statement that this IMHO is a highly subjective matter. I strongly believe in adding value instead of in engaging in endless discount battles and that's a point to which I stand firmly. I can't feel that the price of a single movie ticket is too expensive for any decent game at all and I believe that ADOM is more than decent enough to be rated at that price level.
- I do not think that ADOM easily screws your character. Examples would be welcome, flat bland statements do not make for a good or helpful review.
- Regarding repetitveness I pointed the review to the various modes in all the latest releases that allow you to create a new character (even with extensive customization) with 3-6 clicks (and a name you need to enter). Which hardly can be called repetitive any more. It takes about 5 seconds to generate a new character if you know what you want to play. Naturally if you check all choices and optimize attributes to the last bit this can take much longer. But that is not necessary to enjoy or win the game and thus a conscious player choice.
- And about me being unprofessional: I'm sorry for reacting with an attitude after you snarked at my initial comments which tried nothing but to explain. I believe I'm taking a lot of time and effort to listen to the player community in general and respond appropriately. What I'm done with after 25 years of doing this is taking people seriously who are rude, dumb, trollish or simply unfactual. Yes, then I'm also leaning towards reacting likewise because I am a human being that spent most of those 25 years doing this for fun in my free time without earning money for it. And I come from a generation where burning down trolls was a good sport. But that doesn't mean you generally will find me unprofessional. I welcome you to discuss this with me face to face at Roguelike Celebration next week in San Francisco if you happen to be around that area (see https://roguelile.club). And I'm happy to offer buying you a meal to soothen any hurt feelings.

Thanks for reading
Thomas Biskup
ADOM Maintainer

36007546.review:
ADOM has rapidly become my favourite of the major roguelikes: it's been discussed many times so I won't add too much to that other than my personal love for this stems mostly from the feel of the game. You can tell any art that has had time, effort and love pumped into it: it radiates out and feels just great. ADOM is exemplary in game design, has a multitude of options and is, for the most part, fair. With any roguelike game, imagination plays a key part (the main reason I still play in ASCII, although I must say that the tiles on this Steam release are of a very high quality indeed and will please those whol prefer graphics) and therefore the feel of a game can be most personal to the player. ADOM has just enough fluff and detail in-game to really allow the imagination to play: you can bump your way through many of the early dungeons without much thought for this and without some of the classic RPG elements this might get a little dull, but I think Thomas Biskup has gotten the mix of ingredients just perfect.

Great great game, worthy of the status as major roguelike, certainly one of the best RPG games ever made and you could do a lot worse than supporting the developers by purchasing the Steam version, as it enables them to add new content.

35839149.review:
I've played this game for just shy of four hundred hours at the time of writing, and I've only beaten it twice. There are still locations, quests, items, monsters, spells and secrets that I've never encountered, and a large number of race/class combinations I've never tried. Given all that, I've no doubt I'll end up playing four hundred more.

A lot of the negatives mentioned by other reviews are completely accurate. Yes, it's an incredibly hard, punishing game. Yes, the mechanics are complex and hard to understand at first, and the keybindings are extensive and take a lot of time to remember. It'll be a long time before you make significant progress, especially if you want to avoid spoilers, and some deaths will be unfair. It is not balanced, nor does it try to be.

And yet, it's one of the deepest, most compelling and replayable games I've ever come across. If you're up for a challenge and willing to put in some time to learn the game, you will be rewarded manyfold. Ultimately, it's one of the best games I've ever played, and though I wouldn't recommend it for everyone, if you like the idea of a game to invest a substantial amount of time into for relatively cheap, this is the game for you.

I started playing ADOM approx 15 years ago. It was released 21 years ago on DOS. It is fair to say that this game has replay value and longevity.

With the Steam launch and the NotEye graphics version I find this game to be more approachable as the game provides easier visual clues as to what sort of monsters/items are shown on screen instead of having to remember what is a pink left parenthesis and what is a green at sign.

Overall my score for this game is 4/5 -- I take one away for all the damned one-shots Biskup has reigned down my up-n-coming heros.

33085330.review:
10/10 would stumble through half of the wilderness of the Drakalor Chain blinded by mud not realizing I just have to wipe my 'F'ace again.

With more seriousness though, if you're here reading this, I assume you know what a rogue-like (as opposed to a rogue-lite) is, and what that means in terms of a high learning curve and general gameplay difficulty.
I constantly read the Ancardia Wiki (that's the only way I learned about shift+'f'), and I constantly get my rear-end sliced off and handed to me on a plate. Sometimes I forget I have a healing spell or have a wand, sometimes I just die in an early dungeon to falling rocks or fireball traps, and sometimes I make decent progress, let it go to my head and then get in over my head, and get swarmed by things I can't kill. But I keep coming back for more, because that's the kind of masochist I am.

*spoilers*
Someday, I will make it past level 20 before I get into a situation where I'm in over my head.
Someday after that, I will get really lucky and save Khelevaster, but still die in combat a couple floors down when I had an unidentified wand that would have saved my life.
Someday far in the future, I will be a couple steps from godhood, able to put all of ChAoS at my mercy... and then die once again to random rocks falling from the ceiling because I'm low hp from the aftermath.
And perhaps someday, years down the line, I will beat this game. I will sigh, and slump down into a heap... and play again because I still will have only gotten a normal ending.

Because that's the kind of noob and masochist I am, and that's the kind of game this is.
10/10 would die a million times for a one chance at glory again.

I'm not fan of whole achievement idea in games generally, because I find them worthless and boring to grind. Ups and down:

+Replay value
+Challenges

TLDR: Very challanging, totally worth it.

Without a doubt one of my all time favorite games. I have been playing since 97 when a friend gave it to me on a floppy disc. In no time I was hooked and have been playing since. There is a lot to learn, and the game does not apologize for it's difficulty in any way, but if you like real rogue likes this should be nothing new to you.

On that note, this is a real rogue like game. Much cleaner and better built than Nethack or it's close relatives (Slash/Slash'EM) in my opinion. Well worth the $15 and over coming the learning curve. Typical of rogue like games the learning curve here is a bit steep, but I found it rather enjoyable as well.

It is completely possible to play this game "unspoiled". Everything you need to know to win the game is in the game. NPCs can give you hints, or my favorite is to eat fortune cookies and learn a little something about the game from the message inside. No need to go to the internet to learn the things you need to know, which is a common problem with games of this depth these days. If you want to read ahead and learn from other's experience the communty has documented a ton of stuff to help you understand all the little corners of this game.

Buy the game. Challange yourself.

30784004.review:
Extraordinary game.

This game started as an ASCII roguelike and pretty small, now it is graphical and but not pretty big. It's colossal.

First of all before you start the game you have to understand that the game has kind of a learning curve, there will be a lot of deaths caused by things you did not expect. If you especially hate starting over, the game is not for you. I hate starting over too but not enough to deter me from this masterpiece. There are so many race/class combinations to give you a new kind of game that you are mostly just excited to try again with different tools - if your high elf wizard died early to some trivial door trap, start over with a troll beastfighter. Now you maybe cannot read but hey, the trap that killed the flimsy elf only tickles you. Maybe use those spellbooks you find as missiles now? And if you die again perhaps try a more stealthy approach as a gnomish assassin. You get the idea. 

The monster library is endless and the game story is intriguing, I dunno how anyone can have the intelligence and creativity required to make this game happen but I am glad someone did. It's a very complex and unforgiving RPG - to be able to beat the game honestly you will need a lot of time, brains, patience, nerves and also some luck. ADOM is _not for everyone_ but I still recommend if you like RPG's and a BIG challenge. TIP> use the internet for information, there is a good wiki. EXTRA TIP> to make the most out of the game, disable all form of game saving and go for the true ADOM experience.

30688500.review:
This is not a review. I am just letting people know to disregard any negative reviews concerning keyboard commands and key bindings.  I just played a bit and used my mouse for the entire session.  There are many key commands if you just want to use a keyboard, but ALL of the keyboard commands are listed right next to the written commands.  You do not have to memorize tons of keyboard commands to play ADOM. There's even floating text windows that appear when you mouse over certain things.

ADOM is now streamlined and very user friendly!  I almost didn't purchase this game because of the negative reviews concerning the multitude of keyboard commands. So if you were on the fence about purchasing this game but was worried about having to memorize many keyboard command, it's not true any longer.  You can use your mouse for "most" of the commands.  I never needed to use the keyboard once...

Just by my brief session with the game, I can assure you that this is a quality game made with a lot of love!  There are many options covering all aspects of the game.  The UI is basic, but again has many options and is also mouse driven.  This game has been steamlined and looks to be one of the best roguelikes I have played.  So far I would recommend this game, but I have not played it long enough to really review it.  

So far the game has runs silky smooth on my computer, but crashed when I quit the game.

28524667.review:
For those of you who don't know. ADOM is (originally) an extremely hard, ascii based rouge-like which has been around on multiple formats since the late 90's. Personally I think it's by far the best traditional rogue-like, and I've tried a few over the years.

Even with what would easily be over five hundred hours playing this game over the last 15+ years or so, first on Amiga, then on Windows. I've only ever completed this game once, and even then I was cheating by backing up my save file. Something which is uneccesary in this Steam version, as there is the option to disable perma-death in exchange for a big reduction in points. There are also options to selct optimal birth month, stat rolls, etc. Which saves a LOT of time if you play ADOM as I do with a specific charachter class in mind.

The graphics and sounds actually add quite a bit to the gameplay.  Especially the sound which allows you to hear if you've hit or missed or been hit. And graphics for example; It's much easier to locate the tiny girl in Terinyo when you can see a graphic of a tiny girl instead of a red "t" which under the Windows version could look almost identical to an orange "t" on some monitors.

For those who are unfamiliar with ADOM, even if familiar with other rogue-likes such as Angband, the keyboard configuration will seem a bit alien. But the list of keybindings is readily available in-game by pressing "?" as well as on the title screen, so it shouldn't take too long to get comfortable. For those familiar with ADOM, you'll be pleased to know that it's exactly the same.

Oh, and I don't know if I'm just being distracted by the beautiful hand-pixelled graphics and atmospheric music, but it seems to be just a little bit harder that the text-based ADOM, especially the small mountain cave. Getting a character over level ten can be an achivement.

Is it worth paying fifteen bucks to play a game you can get for free without the graphics/sound? Hell yeah! The only thing I can think of which is wrong with it is the text can be a bit small, but then the display has more lines, so it evens out I guess.
9.2/10

28048522.review:
In addition to everything one would expect from an isometric dungeon crawler:
- randomly generated dungeons
- dozens of character build combinations
- thousands of unique items
- hundreds of unique monsters
This expansive roguelike brings a great many welcome innovations to the genre, like:
- difficulty sliders, to give you precise control over the level of challenge you face. Options such as hunger, permadeath, and treasure drop rates allow you to toggle between a grueling challenge and lightweight game.
- a plot! And it's actually quite good!
- multiple possible endings!
- expansive set piece battles!
- complex puzzles!
- being developed consistently for years!
- global and local high score boards that rank your scores based on your progress and difficulty!

Everything about this game is brilliant, and it just keeps getting better.

Quem não se importa com graficos e tem interesse em sofrer um pouco até se acostumar com a jogabilidade, ADOM é um jogo EXCELENTE com uma jogabilidade simples, mas complicada, e muito dificil (para morrer de forma besta e perder horas de jogo com aquele personagem é facinho).

Como o jogo a principio foi criado para se jogar em MS-DOS ele tem muitos comandos (por ser uma limitação daquela época), quase todas letras e numeros do teclado tem um comando configurado para ela, tem também diferença entre maiúsculo e minúsculo até se acostumar demora um pouco.

Como os jogos atuais tem graficos incriveis em relação a como o ADOM era a principio, colocaram um versão gráfica para  conseguir ter um imerção melhor ao jogo pelo fato de ter algo que você ja consegue visualizar rapidamente sem ter que ficar imaginando como seria o mundo e personagens. Diferente de antigamente que era totalmente em caracteres ASCII com diferentes cores nos caracteres para sinalizar o que era cada coisas seja ela cenário, NPC, monstros ou itens. Kann dieses Spiel nur allen Roguelike-Fans empfehlen. Ja, man stirbt schnell, ja, in die Steuerung und die Spielmechanik muss man ein wenig länger reinfinden als "Guck mal, da sind die Pfeiltasten". Aber das ist ja auch so gewollt, ein Roguelike eben.

Was speziell ADOM ausmacht, ist die unermüdliche Zähigkeit, die nicht nur die Spieler, sondern auch der Autor aufbringt. 26977686.review:
This review is to satisfy the
"Review or update your review of a game you nominated" 
for the 
"Steam Awards Nomination Committee 2016" badge

Also, I voted this for
THE "TEST OF TIME" AWARD

And yes, I recommend this game, but only if you have the patience for hardcore rogue-like games.

Otherwise, you could always save scum like I do. 

ADOM save file folder location: 
My Documents\ADOM\adom_steam\savedg

Then you can create a .bat file for the save file backups. 

Create a folder called "backup" 

Then create a backup.bat file

backup.bat
echo off
copy yourcharactername.svg backup

then a restore.bat file

restore.bat
echo off
delete yourcharactername..svg
copy backup\yourcharactername..svg

Then you can enjoy ADOM with a character save backup. 

However, if you do beat the game, the system will still know how many times you have died and came back.

26907819.review:
ADOM; A game where you can rescue a little girls dog from a deadly cave.....or eat its corpse in front of her(And then give candy to negate the Karma loss!).
In ADOM you can choose to crush the true evil, seal it away or even become it with various ways of achieving any of these(With their own endings)

With an alignment system that means you can be gifted artifacts from a god or be smote where you stand(unless you can work out how to avoid it ;) ) ADOM allows you to do, within the games mechanics, anything you wish; from using a corpse as a throwing weapon all the way up to surviving an angered gods rage as a pacifist.

Equipment is plentiful for all slots with many base types, prefix's, suffix's, bless/curse and extraneous things such as rust. Not only do you have an inventory and equip slots so to do the monsters with some being smart enough to decide to drop their broken heavy spear in favour of a blessed two-handed sword of sharpness.

The only downside, for some people, is the graphics; With the choice between ASCII(text) or Sprite-based those that are looking for "pretty" wont find it here.

Don't trust reviews? Good, check out the latest free version on the Devs very own website (Warning: It's obviously a bit out of date)

26880816.review:
So there are roguelikes, and then there are roguelikes. ADOM is a pretty venerable one, not quite as old or well-known as games like nethack but it's an important one. Why? Well, one thing people attribute to roguelikes pretty often is that they are hard and obtuse. To a certain degree this is true, but not always. Playing a valkerie and knowing how to write Elbereth makes nethack pretty easy, or you can play something like Dredmor or a Mystery Dungeon game to have an easier time. 

But ADOM takes being weird and hard to higher levels. Cats are a constant menace. Funny lizards make you think that wasn't a good idea. Why does this level have so many corpses in it and why does my mouth have tentacles in it? ADOM probably won't give you the answers to these questions without making you work for it. 

And yet we find ADOM here on Steam, with shiny new features that make playing an old fashioned roguelike a little more palatable for people who weren't doing it in the 90s. The updated tileset is excellent, letting characters have personality and making the screen much more clear than the old ASCII symbols while retaining the ability to switch back when you want to see the whole level at once. Perhaps the biggest change is the ability to save and reload (at the cost of reducing your final score, of course). This makes the many, many fatal mistakes that one can encounter in the Draklor Chain a little less punishing. It might not help you from starving right off, but it could keep you from losing right at the start in the Puppy Cave. Then there are the weekly challenges, to add spice to players who are constantly looking for new ways to play. 

All things considered, ADOM is a classic roguelike and the Steam release has a lot to recommend it. If you are a fan of newer roguelikes like Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup or Dungeons of Dredmor and want to dip into older titles, this is the place to be. Plus you can use it as an excuse to send postcards to strangers.

I've been playing this game for almost two decades and still dream about one day beating it between my nightmares of angering the graceful white [b]f[/b] or running into bulky yellow ampersands. Many hours were lost playing randomised round-robin ADOM with my friends. When I eventually got the Steam version I was pleasantly surprised to see that significant development has been made since [url=http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html]the latest free release[/url]. Yes, the game is a double-edged sword. It requires [i]extensive time and research[/i] to get into and the [i]learning curve is steep[/i]. Even so the complexity of the environment, the depth of character development, and the exhiliration of narrowly escaping death and enjoying great rewards is well worth it.

This is a true dungeon crawling RP experience: only play this if you can tolerate no monster memory between characters, running away from encounters often, frequently and often instantaneously dying from nasty traps, as well as working hard to develop your meta skills.

ADOM is an incredibly in-depth and difficult roguelike, well worth the time spent coming to grips with the many intricacies of the controls and game mechanics. - mechanics such as, necromancy, mindcrafting, ventriloquism, appeasing your god, displeasing your god, smithing, crafting, gardening, spending time with lonely monsters, equipment cursing/blessing, an alignment system from chaotic to lawful, affected by the player's actions.

however, this game is not for the faint of heart, and bitter, repeated failure is all but guaranteed. a true classic, there is little hand-holding bar the tutorial which leads to a player experience limited only by your imagination. many epic adventures await, and many tragic insta-deaths. patience and security will lend you a rewarding journey, but be warned - it's not going to be easy.

here are some interesting ways the game will kill you:
-choked to death on your own vomit
-dungeon roof collapses upon you
-turned into a writhing mass of primal chaos
-crushed to death by the weight of your equipment
-old age
-slain by an angry pet
-drowned
-turned to stone by a gorgon's breath
-turned to stone by eating the corpse of a gorgon
-bolted by your god after gravely offending them
-being sacrified to another creature's god
-instantly killed by a death ray
-burned by impure metal as a mist elf
-eaten by a grue
-your worn ring of the master cat explodes because you killed a cat
-your worn platinum girdle slowly squeezing you to death because you sinned

[b](before reading, you can literally get this game free on the website: http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html the downside is that its an older version and the UI isn't as fancy, most in-game stuff is the same)[/b]

I thought I would hate this game, first hour or two learning the keybinds I [i]DID[/i] hate it (you can just take a look at the negative reviews, most of them are people who gave up within hours because of the massive amount of keybinds and the non-use of the mouse), but now it's become the only game I play on Steam.

There is so much to do and so many ways to do them. A single run where I made it almost halfway through the game took me 14-15 hours (don't worry you can save). No two runs can be similar in any way shape or form; the story is always different. The Steam version is the product of [b]22 years of development[/b], and it just got an update recently. You won't find many games with more content than ADoM has to offer.

Keep in mind, however, this being an old-school roguelike, ADoM is by far the hardest game I've played in my life. It is 1 of the 4 "big roguelikes" as people like to honk about, the others being Angband, Crawl, and NetHack, which are not on Steam, but free to download as well.



If you can stomach the "learning how to play" aspect of the game, this is among the best games money can buy you.

24305264.review:
ADOM is a lot like a classic car. It was top of the line in its day and drove very well at the time. For a number of years, it's been sitting in a garage, and the owner recently decided to bring out the car, spruce it up, and get it back on the road. The paint has been touched up, the upholstery has been redone. The car was made before a lot of features you'd expect today were put in, so the owner has got seatbelts put in, and a new sound system, and some other odds and ends. But a lot of the car is still the same... it runs on a diesel engine, standard transmission, no power steering. It's a beautiful car, but it is still, in many respects, a product of its time.

ADOM is much the same. It's a fantastic game. It has more depth and complexity than just about any game out there, and is fiendishly challenging without being unfair (mostly). I've put in more hours into ADOM than probably any other game I've played, donated happily to the Indiegogo campaign, and look forward to the new developments as they come out. But if you've never played Rogue-likes from the 90s, you'll probably be in for a shock, much like if you've never driven without power steering, you'll be in for a shock the first time you try to drive without it. The interface is admittedly clunky, and despite the dev team's best efforts to modernize it, the learning curve is still pretty steep, and figuring out how to perform a given action (let alone when you ought to perform that action) isn't always transparent. I can imagine a lot of players finding this off-putting, and I think if you look at the negative reviews of this game, this is very much the kind of sentiment you'll see. This game isn't for everybody; due both to its difficulty and to its aesthetic, it will probably only appeal to a certain segment of players. Like the classic car.

If you've played ADOM before, you'll probably love it as much as you did then. If you haven't played before, and haven't played a lot of classic Rogue-likes generally, you might want to give the free version on http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html a test drive first.

22104638.review:
ADOM (Ancient Domains of Mystery)  is a roguelike adventure game, developed by a team of 5 people. This review is coming from someone who has not played the original games in the series and has no prior knowledge, and from someone who didn’t grow up playing this type of game either. Please bear that in mind with this review. 

Gameplay is like any other roguelike game, where you get to choose from an array of different characters, and develop levels, statistics and skills as you progress.  The game is played from a top down angel and is very heavily weighted towards stats and what choices you make in whether you succeed or fail.  The game’s tutorial absolutely bombards you with way too much information which personally left more confused compared to when I first started. The controls and UI are quite possibly the worst I have ever experienced in a game too. There is quite literally a different button for every single mechanic in the game. This game made me feel sufficiently stupid because of how much jumble there is on any one screen at any time. The game was telling me to use buttons that I don’t think I have ever used on this keyboard. I am surprised this is one of the most popular roguelikes ever just from going off the usability of the game thus far. 

The graphics are bad, there is no way around it and anyone who says otherwise is purely saying it from a nostalgia standpoint.  The pictures in the screen shots are definitely not what the game looks like on my screen, and I was playing the game in 4k. 

I am still stuck in the tutorial of the game, because of being dumbfounded with the controls and the amount of information being thrown at me but this game if you manage to get into it, will offer you hours and hours of content with a very high replay ability factor also being the main reason behind this. 

I am fully expecting this review to not be very popular given that I have reviewed it before even getting out of the tutorial; and I am clearly missing something about this game since it is so highly rated. But for me, having not grown up playing this type of game, and from someone who is not able to take in abundant amounts of information and learning the most whacky confusing control scheme, I simply cannot recommend it. It is possibly a generation thing, but if you mostly agree with my reviews and enjoy the same games I do, then you may want to eerie on the side of caution when trying this out as it is simply a game I did not enjoy at all.

3) Only recommended when on sale

5) Highly recommended

22098367.review:
Been playing ADOM for over a decade now, and it's easily my favorite roguelike out there.

Compared to other roguelikes:
+More indepth game options(control permadeath, treasure spawn rates, monster difficulty...etc).
+Has an overworld(multiple dungeons, towns, and wilderness encounters).
+A main story quest with multiple endings, as well as several sidequests.
+A relatively comprehensive official wiki.
+Corruption system which grants mutations with both positive and negative effects.
*A dozen races and almost two dozen classes.

Compared to how it used to be:
+A starsign selector.
+Two new races and classes.
+Graphics options of Tiles + Minimap, or classic ASCII.
+Sound effects & music.
+New quests, areas, monsters, dungeon features, and bug fixes.
-Mindcrafters still can't mind control.

21936170.review:
[h1]Ancient Domains of Mystery[/h1]
[i]Developed by: Thomas Biskup , Jochen Terstiege , Zeno Rogue , Krzysztof Dycha , Lucas Dieguez
Published by: Thomas Biskup
Released:  16th Nov 2015[/i]

[h1]Impressions and thoughts:[/h1]

ADOM is one of the 'Gods' of the traditional roguelike genre, starting as a MS DOS game in 1994, continually being  development to this day.  It features several dozen different dungeons, some with fixed layout and others randomly generated each time you play.  It also has an 'overworld' adventure map, which was an unique feature in ADOM's young days.

There are a lot of different character types you can make from a big selection of races and classes who can pursue multiple different endings.  Save the world from ChAoS as a Troll Paladin, or maybe take the place of the elder chaos god Andor Drakon as a Hurthling Farmer? Anything goes.

ADOM has always been and will continue to be freeware, downloadable from the developer site adom.de.  Recent features include the graphical Noteye tileset that vastly improves the visual appeal.

On Steam, the Deluxe version promises a slew of additional features, many of which at the time of this review several months after release have not been realized in the game.  This is a point worthy of critique.  The small development team working on ADOM have always done things in their own pace, which is perfectly fine for a freeware hobby project.  However with a Steam release comes expectations of promises being delivered on.  As much as I love the devs and the wonderful game they've created, this must be pointed out.  While ADOM is a complete game in its own right, the DELUXE version is far from complete.

That bit of complaining aside, ADOM is a beautiful game.  It is a brutal, oldschool roguelike with such a staggering depth that even with the community wiki on hand, it can take years to uncover all its tricks and secrets.  It will kill hundreds of characters, often just when you felt they were getting somewhere before you can even think about beating the whole game.  It has the replayability for the game to still be addicting to play for all those attempts, with all its character variations and random generated nature.  In fact, I recommend this game not for the story and reaching its ending, but for all the journeys your poor doomed characters embark on before they inevitably get crushed.

If you like turnbased dungeon crawling, traditional roguelikes with deep systems that you will keep learning new things in even after years of playing, ADOM comes strongly recommended.  However!  I would suggest playing the freeware version on adom.de first.  Unless you just want to support the developers of course (which you should!).  The Deluxe version of the game on Steam doesn't as of yet add much of features to justify a price tag.  Once implemented I think the Steam version will be safely recommended, as well.

One of the major predecessors to the 'adventure roguelike' genre has finally come to Steam! I have been playing this game for more years than my 'time played' would suggest, and for people who love a good roguelike RPG, I can honestly say that I have yet to find a better one. A huge world (for a roguelike), many quests, secrets, Easter Eggs, character customization, achievements, challenges.... this game is an absolute *gem*. 

Be aware: like all good(?) roguelikes, this is not a game for the faint of heart. Even with an 'easymode' to it, it can have a very steep learning curve, and your deaths will be spectacular. A lot of weight can hang on the Will Of The RNG. The right weapon at the right time, or the wrong roll at the wrong time, can make or break a game. Be aware that while skill counts heavily, it's all too possible to find yourself in a situation where one mislaid trap can be the diffeence between life and death. 

It's a game I wouldn't trade for the world, though, and one that is worth every penny paid for it. If you're a fan of the roguelike genre, this is one not to be missed. Don't pass this up!

I started playing ADOM around 2000-2001 and it was the first roguelike I ever played, and no roguelike has even come close to living up to the standard that this game has set. Well except maybe Dwarf Fortress, but that is a whole different beast.
I played this game by myself and I have played with friends who had set up linux shells with this game on it and we would compete for high scores. I cannot overstate how much enjoyment this game has brough to my life.

This game is tough as nails and it has punished and brutalized me more times that you can imagine. 
And I loved every second.
I have put hundreds if not thousands of hours into ADOM. 
And it was all for free. 
I saw this on the store and bought it instantly. Not a second thought.

Hilariously, even with the new mouse controls, I still play totally with the keyboard. 
After all these years, I still remember every key. This game is in my blood.

I feel I must caution new players who might be thinking of trying this game out that you may find the learning curve a bit intimidating, but please persist. The experience this game provides when you are confident that you know what you are doing is just pure golden. One moment of carelessness may get you killed, but you know that it was your fault. 
Take every character's death as a teaching moment.

Thomas Biskup absolutely deserves every penny of my money.
I know how much effort he has put into this game, his labour of love.
He really deserves my money for all the laughs, the tears, the near misses, the terrifying moments, the foolish mistakes and miscalculations, the mystery, the discovery, the pain, and the joy he has brought to me through this game.

21174809.review:
I was a fan of the original way back in the day, played it constantly. Wrote my own program to auto-backup the saves so I could cheat permadeath when I wanted to. I have played many dungeon crawl games, including Rogue, the OG of the genre. Out of them, this is one of the best. 

A large open world (for the genre) full of quests and NPCs. There is plenty to do and see in ADOM as well as a large selection of Class/Race combanations. The mechanics are perfect. This game was created based on PnP rpgs like DnD, and attempts to recreate this as much as possible. There are a ton of hidden rolls, and many are refrenced in the text. The text really makes it feel like a tabletop rpg, well written and really sets the tone.

ADOM is also Random and unpredictable. You may die on the way to your first town, killed by enemies you stood no chance against, or kick down a door  to find a large demon ready to rip your head off. With permadeath on it is a hardcore dungeon delvers wet dream come true. This game is hard.

But now there are options to turn certain features, like permadeath, off. This opens the door for people like me, who enjoy the style, but dont like always playing a hardcore character. It also makes it easier to really enjoy the story and world without fear of losing your character . The graphics are not cutting edge, and I for one am glad. This is the update the game needed. Havent fiddled with the other game modes, but I theres just so much to do. I am also glad development seems to be continueing, so there may be more content to come. 

So there you go, I love this game, totally worth my money.  If you are into old skool Rogue-Likes and value depth over fancy graphics I think you will too.



ps~Thank you Thomas, for all the hours I have played your game over the years, I bought this almost as soon as it came out on steam, and you deserve every penny. GG

21043405.review:
Since a new update came out recently, I wanted to revise my review for this game after playing it for a lot more.

This game is still an awesome game and I have enjoyed it a lot more than most modern games I've played these days.

Pros: 
Replayability
-Most areas are all randomly generated (save for a couple special places)
-Item drops and artifacts you get are random (you never no what you will get, good or bad)
-You can play the same character type again, and it will feel totally different from your first playthrough!


Tons of Content
-Many areas explore
-Plenty of quests to tackle
-Multiple endings (you can beat the game quickly or try and complete an ultra ending)

Customizability
-Many classes to choose from (ranging from easy to difficult in terms of playstyle)
-Many races to also choose from (you can be a Human, Dwarf, Elf, Drakeling, Orc and more!)
-The new point buy system is awesome and more improved! Make your fighter have lots of strength and toughness but little learning
-Different playstyles: You're wizard doesn't have to wear cloth robes only, have him wear plate armor and attack with weapons (assuming you got the strength for it ;))

Graphics/UI/Music
-The graphics and UI are very nice looking, especially after this update. The animations are nice as well, and soon there will character customization (I'm really excited for this one)!
-The UI updated also looks very good (although it does have a tendency to get in the way when your character is at the top of a map. Hopefully this gets fixed soon)
-The music has also been improved as well, and there are a lot of good tracks in this game

Support
-Game is still being supported years after it came out 
-New content is planned even after this new update (new artifacts, levels, quests; Go check out the adom forums or the creators twitter for previews)

With any good game, there are also some cons:

Cons:
Difficulty
-When learning how to play, the game can be rather harsh (hunger, corruption, etc.). The difficulty barrier isn't as large as something like Dwarf Fortress, but it is there. You have to be able to learn from your mistakes. If you can't do that, this game might not be for you. If you stick with it though, it's a rewarding game.
-If you do have problems, the community is quite helpful (as long as you are willing to learn). There is an active adom community in the steam forums as well as in the roguelikes discord chat. Feel free to stop by!
-You can also turn off certain things like hunger and corruption, or you can also play with reloadable games if you want to play that way

Key Bindings: 
-This game has so much in it, and there are a lot of key bindings that are somewhat unintuitive. If you might not be able to figure it out, it can be quite frustrating. The game does give quick hints now, so its helpful, but this complaint is one I see a lot from negative reviews, and I do agree with it. 

Bugs:
-Like many games, there are always going to be bugs you run into, and ADOM is no exception. The game runs quite well, but every now and then you will run into something that might be a problem. If that does happen, be sure to submit a bug report, otherwise they wont be able to be fixed.

Tedium:
-One thing that I might complain about is there is a small amount of tedium in the game. You have be constantly eating, sacrificing for piety, managing inventory, avoiding cats, going to certain areas at certain times etc. It's not a huge deal, as imo it adds an interesting twist to the game. However, it might be a turn off for some people, so I thought I would just bring that up.
-A lot of knowledge can be found from the adom wiki, which is maintened quite well by the community. 

Past these cons, I love this game, and would highly recommend it to anyone who loves roguelikes!

If you are on the fence about this game, there is a free version you can download from here: http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html

It's a much older version, but soon it will be updated with some of the new content.

20952757.review:
This is my absolute favourite rogue like. I have been playing for at least 10 years and the new steam version adds some welcome changes.

I love this game simply because it has all the awsome features you would expect from a roguelike but with a world map.
The world map is always the same and features a lot of entrances to dungeons and villages, each being different in sometimes a variety of ways, and for the most part are randomized every game. this leaves you free to pick and choose which quests you want to take. Once you have figured out a lot of the early quests you can choose to skip the ones in which the rewards do not interest you.

My one criticism of this game is that the religion system sucks. It's not interesting, the rewards for becoming uber pious are kind of lackluster when i consider how grindy and unenjoyable reaching that point is. Fortunately it is not necesary to concern yourself with it. I compare this game in this regard to dungeon crawl and IVAN which both have interesting and fun religion systems.

Another aspect of this game that i like compared to other roguelikes, such as dungeon crawl, is that the skill system is very rewarding. some skills are passive and just buff your character but others have specific applications.
you can pick pockets, pick locks, build bridges, craft arrows, tame animals, brew potions, smith armour...
For me this adds a layer of character that helps me role play.

I recomend this game however if you do not have any experience with roguelikes i suggest you do some reading about the genre as this game is brutal and, other than the games basic mechanics, this is mostly a trial by fire. 
I am adamant about not using guides or cheating, however this game is so brutal that despite knowing all i need to know i have never managed to win even a single time despite using the adom guidebook and perusing forums for additional insight.

Very solid game with extremely in depth mechanics. 
This game is very unforgiving, so newbies to the RPG gerne beware.  If you haven't played many "classics" like baldur's gate, icewind dale ect. You will maybe feel a bit alienated on the D&D based mechanics. None the less, once you understand the system it is very logical and mathematic. 

Anyone who has played a decent amount of RTS games or MMORPG's will not have a hard time learning and memorising the different keys used to play the game. There are quite a few different commands and key combinations, it can seem intimidating at first. Honestly, there's only about 10-15 commands you will actually use early game. You learn everything fluently as you play by occasionally going into the help menu for key bindings.

The game is quite unforgiving and does require a lot of trial and error. It will teach you to be careful and methodical. Also with the perma-death feature, you will have to learn how to leg it. All in all I feel the game is very fair. There are occasional frustrating deaths like getting critical hit by a rat who you thought was absolutely no threat but most of the time it is your own fault if you died. 

I would definately recommend this game to anyone who love's very indepth and challenging RPGs.

ADOM is the first steam game I have ever returned.   I typically read many reviews beforehand - so it's not necessary to return games.  In the case of ADOM, most of the reviews fail to mention any of the issues associated with the numerous keybindings required to play the game in an enjoyable fashion.  I didn't notice until after returning the game that most of the negative reviews were unfairly down voted for mentioning critical issues associated with poor mouse controls.

The controls are clunky and the game requires too much memorization of key bindings to play.  Most of the positive reviews posted on Steam are likely from long time players who memorized the long list of key bindings a long time ago.  For new players - this will likely be a highly unpleasant experience because of the aforementioned poor user interface and reliance on key bindings. 

There are free versions of this game that you can try out before buying.  I highly recommend any new player to this game to download a free version and try out the controls first hand before purchasing on Steam.  You will easily discover if the controls bother you or not.   Like the other reviews that mention ADOM's outdated reliance keybindings and clunky controls, I expect my review to be down-voted.  I'm okay with that if it means saving other Steam users money.  The limited time listed of me playing this game is actually overstating my time spent on this game.  90% of that time was actually spent reading up on one of the many outdated keybindings required to play before deciding to uninstall the game.

20163870.review:
One of the classics, this might be one of the finest - and most difficult - roguelike RPGs you can play. The level of detail and breadth of options are immense and it remains one of the most tense and thrilling challenges any player can look for.

The Steam edition is nicely cleaned up with a few fun additions and a new graphic tileset. There's next to no animations, but it's readable and the character sprites do change as you add/remove equipment. Overall a nice addon to the classic game. Also included is an actual (if short-lived) tutorial to help get players acquianted, but that's really just a token gesture and it doesn't offer all that much advice.

Pros:
- Excellent if you want a challenge.
- Extremely high level of replayability.
- Excellent attention to detail.
- Good variety of classes/races/playstyles.

Cons:
- Obtuse UI and keybindings can be frustrating at times.
- Learning curve like a steep cliff - prepare to die a lot!
- Graphics tileset is barely an improvement over ASCII - this game isn't a looker.

Overall I'd give it 5/7, a perfect buy.

20124244.review:
The counter shows that I've spent 28,4h with ADOM on Steam. That is only partly true. The truth is that I've been playing this game since August, 1998. So it's basically like... 17 years. Soon my playtime will be permitted to buy alcohol and smokes. I remember the time when with my best friend we sent a postcard to the creator, Thomas Biskup, because back then ADOM was "postcard-ware" - when you wanted to thank the developer, you just had to go to the post office and send a postcard. It is worth every penny considering the game's been free for over 20 years and you can still check the free, older versions at adom.de

Now ADOM is on Steam and for ~15 euro you can experience one of the hardest, most challenging, vague (in terms of "what should I do now?") and merciless games of all time. ADOM is one of the legendary roguelike games. That means permadeath after 30hrs of game, that means all your scrolls getting soaked because you forgot to grab that damned blanket, that means drowning, because the ice you created with ice bolt just cracked and you and all your belongings are gone, that means getting burned because one of your fire resistance rings isn't blessed, that means almost crying when you see game message stating: *THUMP*. Finally that means checking every class combination and getting acquainted with ADOM Bible or some other, newer guidelike stuff, because you think that there is some magic formula, a cheat, a "best class combination -> enter google" that will allow you to "win". That if you create a trollish healer born under the Candle star sign, you will magically plow through the Caverns of Chaos and win the game. 


And then, on level three of some random dungeon you stumble upon undead vault.


ADOM went through a lot during over 20 years of development - now you have graphics engine, you can choose a lot more during character creation, finally - you have a "cheat engine" so to speak, so you can try to go through the whole game without permadeath - as far as I understand, I've never tried this mode, because ADOM is in a way something that games like "Dark Souls" aspire to - you die, you learn, you die again. After a thousand deaths, you die once more, but you try again. 

During the "ADOM hiatus" a lot of other games emerged - ToME, Elona, and finally - a lot of lighthearted roguelike(like)s. 

I never thought I would live to see this day. The king is back.

Current Review, January 2018:

"A top, polished Roguelike" - TL;DR

(First off, my "offline mode" time doesn't seem to show up...) I have been playing the ADOM 3 beta and now the final v3.0.6... Man, what a total overhaul and awesome set of improvements! The UI now scales to whatever size screen you have, and it works great on my WQHD Alienware 13R3 to my rMBP to my little tiny GPD Pocket. Next, the simplification of the key commands is huge - it makes the game much easier to play. The sound and graphics/animation are improved, the questing has nice pop up text, and in general everything is much more polished. There are more game modes, etc. This is easily one of the most polished Roguelikes on Steam now - and there is a lot of competition. (Frankly quite a few are also worth playing, a testament to the dedication of their creators and the benefit of us the gamers.)

Previous Review, October 2016:

As of the latest beta, R71 in October 2016, I re-purchased this game and have played it a few hours. While I have only played it on an 11" MacBook Air so far, I can say that all my complaints about the previous version have been addressed. The game looks good and operates properly as soon as you run it. It has a steap learning curve, but that's not entirely unexpected in this sort of game. The tile graphics are reasonably nice.

Original Review, December 2015:

This was the first ever Steam game I returned; it's that bad, at least on my Mac. First, basic computer program sequences didn't work. For example, I couldn't figure out how to quit out of the game and the standard Command-Q and menu items did nothing. I eventually pulled up the "Force Quit" menu and killed the program that way (equivalent to kill -9 for Unix users). Second, the fonts and window don't scale properly, and there are about 37,000 settings for these things, none of which produce a nice, usable look and feel on fonts unless you leave the window a tiny thing on the screen. On a 2560x1440 or 1920x1080 screen it is just insanely silly. Third, the tutorial is more annoying than helpful. It randomly pops up a super-small text box that is ridiculously difficult to scroll through telling you things that are generally irrelevant at the time. Sure, it's a roguelike and so there are tons of commands, but at least list them for me in some sort of importance order on the side of the screen or something.

All in all, I've been playing Roguelikes since, literally, Rogue in the 80s and this was one of the worst experiences ever. I returned the program to Steam and downloaded the free one. I've spent a few hours with the free one and found no way around any of these problems above. If you want a truly great Roguelike to buy here on Steam, look at ToME instead. It's cheaper, easier to learn, much more beautiful, and "just works."
