I don't usually write reviews, but this game is good enough to warrant writing one. I haven't played this game before it came out on steam, so I'm not really blinded by nostalgia goggles. But this game is good, only it's the toughest learning curve I've ever experienced, even harder than X-Com Long war mod. To those expecting to play something where it's possible to win as long as you play right, turn away. However for those willing to preservere through tens and eventually hundreds of character deaths this game is rewarding. It's sort of like crossing a minefield, where the signs are all in a different language, so you don't know where the mines are or what to do. And take my advice, the tutorial isn't that good, it's better to wiki everything, unless you are really really masochistic and wanna learn everything through dying.

But once you learn the tricks of the game, it's enormously fun. For example, I kept starving to death, because I didn't realize you could eat corpses and nobody minds. No karma lashbacks, and no getting sick, unless you eat something poisonous. Then I finally got past the third dungeon. That's right, I've died multiple times and still hadn't gotten past that third beginner dungeon. Then I made the mistake of wandering into a random dungeon and getting killed by a room full of giants. 

Anyways the perks of this game are:
 1 it's very difficult, sort of like demon souls. 
2. It's a delight for people who like to imagine what the fights look like instead of seeing it. Like when I accidentally wandered into a water trap with a fluff ball in my backpack and gremlins started appearing out of nowhere. I was like "Oh, ****" and they constantly multiplied around my Monk character. Hundreds of dead gremlins later, the floor was flooded with blood and my monk had came through unscathed. 
3. There are many, many, many different ways to play the game. You could be the unarmed monk,(my favorite), the untouchable wizard(too frail in melee for my tastes), or the cunning assassin(kept dying, cuz he doesn't start with heal) and much much more. Apparently there's a race that starts with the spit acid ability or something. 

Oh well, this reviews getting a bit too long. In short, this is a good game for those willing to put up with how hard core it is and are willing to put up with the ridiculous key mappings.

19686425.review:
For me, this is a classic game that's improved by a tileset that expands the playability for new and old players alike.

This game is part of the big three formative roguelike games that set the benchmark for this type of packrat, dungeon crawling, permadeath that's so wonderfully additctive. The three consist of Angband (specifically T.O.M.E and its predecessors for me), Nethack and (of course) ADOM.

ADOM was probably the game the least like the others in terms of how everything worked. It allowed for extremes of overly complicated OR remarkably simple gameplay and has a depth far beyond any roguelike from its time and for that matter most roguelikes ever.

Once you've spent some time getting sufficiently spoiled (you kinda have to to finish the game), you'll end up chasing ultra endings and then you can pretty much kiss your free time goodbye. I'd definitely recommend this game provided you understand that there is a learning curve and you take your time to get into it.

19540563.review:
По правде говоря, это даже не Rogue-like, это ADOM-like. Потому что ADOM - не меньшая классика, чем собственно Rogue. При этом, в отличие от своих современников, живет и здравствует до сих пор. Обзавелась музыкой, графическим движком (в котором можно и вид из глаз включить, если очень надо) с добротными иконками, контекстными меню и прочими атрибутами времени.
Конечно, ADOM не так удобна как современные поделки. Здесь и отпугивающее новичков многокнопочное управление, которое никто не будет вам разжевывать (хотя в новых версиях вроде пытаются сгладить порог вхождения), и сотни непонятных, весьма ситуативных, навыков и талантов, и, конечно, смерть буквально за любым углом. Думаете в других рогаликах легко умереть? Это вы ADOM не видели. 
Всё это компенсируется тоннами веселья, огромным количеством возможностей и уникальным геймплеем для каждого класса, расы и даже добрых/злых героев. А еще обширным миром, эпической историей и медленным превращением в демона (всегда интересно, что на этот раз у вас вырастет).
Где еще увидишь классическую игру, которая обновляется до сих пор? И это не сиквел и не ремастер от чужих людей. Это та самая ADOM. Здесь всё прекрасно. И отлажено декадами любовной разработки. И чем дальше - тем лучше. Присоединяйтесь.

19457844.review:
I had been playing the graphically simplified version available at the original since 1998/1999.

It was one of the best ASCII roguelikes then and now, with all the new stuff it has become just THE game I am playing all the time...

But let me explain WHY do I not need any other games.

ADOM at Steam gives me the true feeling of constant growth, immersion, improvement, a shifting challenge system that changes constantly and is always just a bit less difficult than the impossible...

The graphics and sound are there - no less, no more. However, for an old ASCII fan like me, they create a nice atmosphere in a quite smart way as they are no less and no more than a formal aesthetic addition to the already complex, deep and well implemented game system.

What I do not like - actually what I HAAAAATE is the fact that I had to set the autosave backup file to 50 game turns, as - but for save scumming - I would have lost EVERY save file I had tried to recover... unfortunately, the game would often crash while trying to save the game. Some forum members say it is just a paranoidal behavior, but should I choose between frustration and safety, I definitely aim for the second one.

What I do like - nothing less and nothing more than all the features of the good old "Ancient Domains Of Mystery" from the late '90s, that is many locations, tons of stuff to find/get/steal/buy, many skills divided info combat marks, spell specialization levels, morrowind-like main skills, naturally changing mental, physical and miscellaneous attributes... Simply every game is completely different, full of surprises.

What everyone should like: every time you achieve something the game rewards it to you. Maybe it won't tell you that directly, but after a few (hundred/thousand...) deaths the world shouls start resembling a living organism that is constantly growing and modifying its contents...

This game is for the patient and strong of will ;)

19439495.review:
Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of indie rogue-like Ancient Domains of Mystery (ADOM). ADOM was released on November 16, 2015 on Steam by a team headed by Thomas Biskup, including: Jochen Terstiege, Zeno Rogue, Krzysztof Dycha & Lucas Dieguez. 

(NOTE: This review was produced by using a key for the game that was provided by the Developer/Publisher)

Video Review:

https://youtu.be/zMMjOCStQfE

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:

STEEP learning curve. Sky high difficulty. Permadeath. TON of replayability. Short on Graphics, Audio.
3/5 but a MUST if you're a rogue-like fan. 


The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:

This has been a very difficult game for me to review. It is a solid game. I am totally getting the hang of it just fine and enjoy the genre. However, these controls are still stuck in 1994. The graphics and sound are too. But wait, there is a LOT more to this game. First, the character creation alone is immensely deep. It's really great. Oh sure, you can randomize your hero/anti-hero (yup, you can be evil. why not?), their class, race, stats. You can also choose them yourself. There are quite a few to choose from. Even better, you go through a nice little quiz (or you can randomize this too) to determine some things about your character. This makes for tons of different combos and ways to play the game. I absolutely LOVE this aspect of this game. It is straight RPG with it's abilities, talents, etc. right down to rating them by dice roll and modifier. The controls though. It takes a long time to master these controls. SO much going on all over the keyboard. I feel like some of this could be somewhat simplified, but maybe I am wrong. There really is an crazy amount of depth to this little rogue-like. Fully fleshed out tons and NPC's to be found. All in all, for your average gamer there is a lot to consume here. This is not light gaming at all. More like a Paradox game or Wargaming (a la Ageod games, etc.) there is a lot to master before being able to fully enjoy this game. As you unlock all of this though, it is very rewarding. 


Avg. gamer score would rate out at a 2/5. If you take your time with this one and learn it well, or are already a fan of real rogue-likes though, you'll find this to be a 4/5. Let's split the difference and call it 3/5. 

Happy Gaming!

19426525.review:
ADOM is one of the big classical roguelikes, with 20 years of development. I had played it before the kickstarted campaign for the graphical version and had enjoyed it then, and I enjoy it now even more. It just offers a lot of depth and complexety, I can really dive into the game. The world really feels alive. I also enjoyed TOME, the other great classical roguelike, but somehow I always preferred ADOM. TOME just feels more like game, with its MMO-like skills, while ADOM has the typical quirkiness and complexety of games like nethack, just with a persistent overworld and an actual story, which for me is more immersive.

I like the music, the tilesets and the many possible options, the mouse control. The loading times are pretty much non-existent, which isn't the case for TOME for example. But it still expects much the users to use the non-intuitive outdated old keyboard-shortcuts.

ADOM is hard and unforgiving. The new ingame tutorial doesn't change that. I would recommend reading the beginners guides on the wiki and the ingame manual. It's a game for people who have a lot of patience and are prepared to die early. I contrast to most rogue-lites and also many roguelikes, such as TOME, I always grow attached to my characters, so having them die is even more painful.

Tl;dr: ADOM is still one of the best games for roguelike fans who like depth and are prepared to die a lot and I am positvely surprised of the technical overhaul. But it's still nothing for people who simply want to explore a world and don't like reading manuals.

19425796.review:
I learned the basics of this game about 1,5 years ago and have since then been playing it fairly regularly. Haven't managed to finish one yet, but the great thing about this game is that it doesn't really matter that much. It's not about winning. It's about your character, that you'll be scared for, that you'll pray for, that you'll coddle up and train. You'll be angry at fate, god or just the rng, you'll laugh at stupid deaths, you'll get surges of adrenaline at the sight of that out-of-depth monster around the corner and be immensely relieved when you make it to the next staircase without being followed. Pride when you get out of a situation that looked completely desperate by using your wits, disbelief when you finally identify your stuff and see that you've been carrying around 2 (!!) amulets of life saving, anger at yourself when you lose that really promising character just because you didn't stop playing in time (when you noticed your eyes started itching and your vision got a bit blurry, but hey, you just couldn't leave the game at that point, no way...)
I'm really no game expert, I don't have any comparison to other roguelikes or any other computer games for that matter. But what I love about ADOM is that it's creating stories. Of course there is the ingame storyline, but it's also creating stories in your mind. Even in plain ascii mode, maybe especially there. Your heartrate goes up at the sight of a yellow & and you start hating the sight of any kind of f. You just have to admire (and love) the simplicity of that!
I'll admit that it takes some time to get into it and figure out all the commands, but that's only a small price to pay for everything this game has to offer!

19388103.review:
Imagine that you're a powerful warrior, raiding a dungeon. Enemies falling under your blows left and right, it doesn't even matter what type of beast you just encountered, they all go down just after one or two blows from your greatsword. You happily hoard treasures while mumbling something about having no real challenge. Then as you raid another of the countless rooms you suddenly see a ghost. Easy you think, you fought many of these and they are more annoying than anything. But then pops up another and another and another... a whole horde of ghosts. You fight but it's no use, each time you slay one, several others drain you with their touch. You turn to run but you cannot navigate the the tight corridors as well as these incorporeal beings. It is only a few seconds from there that you drop dead... drained till you collapse of old age.
That's one way an ADOM game goes.

In another you are a powerful mage, having no trouble burning, freezing or electrifying whatever you encounter. That is until you meet an enemy that commands even greater magical powers and easily no-sells whatever your arsenal of spells throws at it. What now? Drink a potion? Use a scroll? Run? Too late in any case. As the only tunnel leading away from the enemy already has an angry giant blocking it. Struggle or go out swinging?
And that's another way an ADOM game may go.

But perhaps you won't even be this lucky, you might be a looser who eats the first kobold, realizes his error once vomiting the contents of their stomach and then be unfortunate enough to meet a ghul, becoming paralyzed by its touch and choking on your own vomit.

Or you'll explode attempting to perform alchemy. Or you'll get bit by something poisonous and realize that without antidotes you're just on a timer to your death. Or you'll read a cursed book at a VERY bad time. Or you'll decide to stand on an obsidian altar while a particularly religious orc is in the same room. Or if you're really lucky you'll live long enough to die attempting to challenge a physical god.

In short ADOM is great for creating an emergent mini story of your own character's struggle (and likely death), offering a ton of freedom and depth, but also demanding patience, dedication and application of one's own brain to learn the game. Those who can handle it can expect a deep and rewarding experience as it is a much bigger achievement to beat superpowered bad guy when you're just a frail mortal who can be blown away at every wrong step.

Now if the game had more polish in terms of graphics and animation and a much friendlier UI I'd have no trouble to recommend it to pretty much everyone, if only for the hillarious ways one can meet their demise. This way, expect to invest a hour or two just to get the hang of the basics and then the rest of your life mastering the rest.

19384992.review:
ALERTE: Excellent jeux !

ADOM est une perle. Un petit bijou vidéoludique, qui ressemble pas mal à mon jeux préféré (Tales of maj'eyal, TOME,  pour ne pas le nommer). C'est un magnifique Rogue-like.

Un petit avertissement tout de même: ADOM c'est comme une voiture. Il faut apprendre à l'utiliser. Et au début c'est difficile, on pense qu'on y arrivera jamais. Puis après, comme pour le voiture, on fait 50km en pensant à ce qu'on va faire à manger, et la voiture se pilote automatiquement.
ADOM c'est pareil. Les commandes sont assez barbares. En plus il y'en a des dizaines (marcher, parler, prier, tremper des objets dans l'eau, envoyer des sors, utiliser des torches, manger, etc... etc... etc...).
Il ne faut pas se laisser intimider par ces commandes barbares. Elles deviendront à 99% automatique.

Attention encore à une chose, ADOM ne vous prend pas par la main. Je ne vous cache pas qu'au début vous ne saurez pas trop ou aller, dans quel ordre aborder les dongeons. Alors là il y'a 2 écoles:
1 l'expérimentation. A force d'essais et d'erreurs, vous aurez une bonne idée du parcours à faire (ou à éviter).
2 Le wiki d'ADOM. Il est super bien fait. Et il permet aux impatients (comme moi) de gagner un peu de temps au début.

Dernière chose, le jeu est en anglais. A ma connaissance pas de patch FR. Mais il y'a vraiment peu de texte à lire (surtout description des sors et des talents). Un niveau d'anglais très basique est largement suffisant pour profiter à 100% d'ADOM.

Bon voilà, c'était les côté "négatifs" du titre. Maintenant pour le reste.... Ben c'est que du positif.
Déja la durée de vie... A 30h de jeux, j'en suis au début du jeux (je commence à survivre régulièrement jusqu'à la ville des nains). Et je prends un immense plaisir à découvrir les subtilité du jeux.
Les différentes classes sont intéressantes, et il y'en à vraiment bcp.

En plus n'étant pas du tout un habitué des jeux de rôle à l'ancienne, je découvre aussi le système d'alignement (loyal, neutre, chaotique), ainsi que le système d'objets bennis/maudits/non-maudits.
C'est très intéressant.

Franchement ADOM c'est comme TOME. On y pense toute la journée, et on se jette dessus dès qu'on rentre à la maison.
Très peu de jeux m'ont fait cet effet dans ma vie.
En parlant de TOME, il y'a une différence notable avec ADOM. La gestion de l'inventaire. Dans ADOM, l'inventaire n'est pas illimité. Et il dépend de la force du personnage. Il y'a aussi la gestion (basique) de la faim.
Même si cette gestion de la faim est problématique dans les premières heures du jeux, une fois les bases assimilées, ce n'est plus un problème.

Le nombre d'ennemis est très varié pour le moment (je suis au "début" du jeux). Et j'en ai rencontré des dizaines de différents. Humanoïdes, bêtes, insectes, dragons, démons et autres machins fantastiques font parties du zoo ADOM,
Le nombre d'objets est aussi impressionants. Batons, haches, épées, dagues, massues, arcs, fouets, etc... etc... etc... 
A ce sujet un petit regret. Notre équipement n'est pas toujours représenté sur notre perso. Certains objet le sont, d'autres non... 


Bon, j'ai assez perdu de temps. Je repars dans affronter les dongeons obscurs d'ADOM ! (en mode de création de charactère aléatoire, car ça me permet de découvrir pas mal de classes/combinaisons sympa).

19321748.review:
So after 52 hours of play I'm finally writing a review, and then giving up and moving on to something else.  There is a small list of reasons, but it comes down to the fact that the game just isn't much fun.  Perhaps that's a symptom of being 'roguelike', perhaps not.  

Pros
- easy to get started, play a while and then stop.  ei no load times, no startup ads to watch, no fancy graphic splash screen

Cons
-  Vast majority of games end in you dying.  Since this is permadeath all the time invested is lost.  Period.
- Most of the things that kill young characters (hunger, traps you can't detect on doors you must go through), poisons you can't cure, monsters that one-hit-kill and who are also faster than you are) you have no possibility of avoiding.  The game doesn't attempt to balance things, it mostly just rolls RNG's and eventually you die.
 - Your character rarely knows anything about the equipment/potion/buffs.  You could die with a potion of healing in your possession and have no possibility of finding out.
 - Even if you choose a class that allows you to see cursed/uncursed status, the game has undetectable cursed items to saddle your character with usless sh*t.
 - Game does a very poor job at allowing balanced characters.
 - Too many things completely invulnerable to player attacks/spells, and very little chance to determine what could be effective against them before you die.
 - If you need something (food particularly, healing, a decent weapon, an identify scroll) you will never find it.  If you don't need it, the stuff drops like rain.  And of course this lack is going to kill you.

Pretty much the game is more of a fancy RNG, rather that someting that is fun.   Some will find this fun, most people will find it frustrating and unrewarding.  And the fact that it kills you repeatedly without any possibilty of not dying makes it more fruitless.

19304090.review:
Мнение об этой игре у меня скачет с тех пор, как я начал ПЫТАТЬСЯ ее пройти - то она мне нравится, то начинает невероятно бесить. Это, наверное, самый ебанутый и беспощадный рогалик из всех, что я видел. 

Игра напоминает минное поле, по которому игрока пускают гулять без миноискателя. Умереть тут можно практически от чего угодно - враги не являются непосредственно главной проблемой. Вполне можно быть убитым... дверью, которую вы пытаетесь выбить, потому что у вас нету нужного (именно нужного) ключа или заклинания, взламывающего замки. И если в некоторых случаях опасностей можно избежать благодаря осторожности и внимательности, то иногда все совершенно выходит из-под контроля. Вы можете наступить в ловушку с ядом, который будет травить персонажа до тех пор, пока тот не испустит последний вздох. Один из моих персонажей страдал от отравления больше 500+ ходов, пытаясь перебить эффект яда навыком "первая помощь", использовав при этом 2 раза помощь своего бога для восстановления здоровья. Но все было тщетно. Хорошо, если есть средство, которым можно снять отравление, но порой такие проблемы возникают в самом начале, когда под рукой обычно ничего нету.

Еще один неприятный момент - это местные тайлы. Это, пожалуй, ЕДИНСТВЕННЫЙ роуглайк, в котором у меня появилось желание переключиться в ASCII-режим. Местный визуальный стиль очень яркий, "пряничный" и, на мой взгляд, не соответствует игровой атмосфере. Но это, конечно, дело вкуса - проблема здесь в другом. Сами тайлы очень неточные. Довольно часто описание монстра или чего-то еще не соответствует его изображению. Наткнувшись на бородатого гиганта-качка, не удивляйтесь, если в тексте будет сказано, что это женщина. Тоже самое с описанием игрового персонажа - у него могут быть голубые глаза и рыжие волосы на бумаге, а на деле и то, и другое коричневого цвета. Я не думаю, что человеку, отвечающему за создание тайлсета, было бы сложно сделать несколько тайлов под каждую комбинацию волос/глаз, так что причина их отсутствия вводит меня в небольшой ступор.

Еще хуже дела обстоят с местными зонами. По описанию они очень разнообразные, конечно. Тут у нас и пещеры, и различные подземелья, крипты, даже подземный лес есть. Но на самом деле, все, что находится под землей - это серые кирпичные коридоры. Неужели так сложно ХОТЯ БЫ просто использовать другие цвета в разных данженах? Это уже было бы лучше чем то, что мы имеем на данный момент. Сильно был удивлен, увидев другой "лейаут" в пирамиде, выполненной в египетском стиле.

С управлением тут тоже не все гладко. Куча неудобных хоткеев, которые вам придется запоминать и использовать всю дорогу. И ладно, если это одна буква, так нет - бывает и такое, что надо нажать что-то вроде "w?" (это, кстати, команда для авто-исследования местности - максимальное "удобство", ага). Некоторые команды можно было запросто сгруппировать на одну кнопку. Например, закрытие/открытие дверей. Но нет. Складывается такое впечатление, что в подобном садистском подходе к управлению был замысел создателя. АДОМ, на минутку, делается еще с 94 года. Очень грустно, что за это время ничего не было предпринято в данном направлении.

В общем и целом, игра явно не рассчитана на новичков жанра. Если вы как раз такой, но хотите приобщиться - начинайте лучше с чего попроще: Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup или Tales of Maj'Eyal. Последний даже есть в стиме, и он очень нуб-френдли. Для тех, кто все-таки решил взяться за АДОМ, знайте - вас ждет боль и порой невыносимая фрустрация, но вместе с этим лихие приключения, веселые проигрыши (да, такое тоже бывает) и НЕВЕРОЯТНАЯ глубина геймплея. 

А я надеюсь, что став получать хоть какие-то копейки за свой труд, Бискуп всерьез займется банальным удобством и, конечно, запряжет человека, отвечающего за визуальную часть, чтобы тот хоть что-то уже сделал с местным убогим тайлсетом. 

Я хочу поставить здесь нейтральную оценку, но ее нет, поэтому я остановлюсь на негативной.

19296585.review:
First things first: Be prepared! ADOM is a demanding and difficult game with permadeath coming at you around every corner. Several secret handshakes that you just got to learn about the hard way. And it's not even really fair at all times. Also you will be consulting a wiki often.

However,

The sense of reward in this game is unparalleled. When you kill that Ancient Chaos Wyrm with one tremendous blow from your Vanquisher, getting revenge for those five other promising characters who died to him. Or when you finally get that one race/class/sign combo running properly that you've been trying for ages. 

There is a lot of death in this game no doubt, but the huge variety you can have with character creation added to the general randomness of the game makes every adventure significantly different. The replay value of this game is immense. Dying means that you get to try something new once again!

As you start out, you might be spending as much time reading a wiki as you are playing. That's okay, there are no real spoilers in this game. Knowing everything beforehand does not really affect your experience in any negative way. And there is a fun sense of mystique; even after years of play you'll be learning new things.

The steam edition packs this classic of a game in a neat and functional package. Definitely worth the price when it comes to amount of gameplay. Also worth it for the veterans. Though if you are very particular to ascii graphics (though you can play this version in ascii aswell), you might not find enough new features as of yet.

Definitely one of the better games ever made!

19273897.review:
I posted a review within hours of release. For some reason it isn't on here, so I'm trying again.

This game is to roguelikes what Baldur's Gate is to CRPGs. After playing for over ten years, I can safely say that this is one of the best games I've ever played. The reason for this is it's strict dedication to its core mechanic -- you, dying.

One of the best descriptions I've ever heard of game mechanics was concerning Dark Souls, in that (paraphrased) "this is a game that is fair to the player -- always FAIR -- and the difficulty does not surprise you if you pay attention."

ADOM is like this. Sort of. Instead of there being ways to see what's ahead and then killing you a la Dark Souls, ADOM's core mechanic isn't actually dying. That's the means to teaching you. You will suffer legitimate losses of equipment, stats, companions, or everything you have in a gripping, slow or numbing, painless death. Then, you are expected - required - to learn from that experience in your next character.

This shows in everything that the game does. RPG classes in 99% of RPGs are meaningless. In ADOM, some are similar to eachother, but every class has at least one unique quality to them that will change the entirety of the game. Races are the same, with each having a sort of opposite, such as the Mist Elves and Trolls; M.Elves have unstoppable magical capabilities and dodging, but Trolls have towering health WITH regeneration (the MOST coveted skill in the game) and can massacre just about anything (can I just say Troll weaponsmith w/sword of sharpness? Yes, I CAN say that!) (... right before I died).

I've been playing off and on, but the adventures have been memorable. I was introduced to the game by scumming and knew too little to understand that this was NOT as the game was designed. Once I found the ADOM Guidebook online, I started playing rogue (with a little experimentation). My first winning playthrough was a Human Fighter, Phaeton; he ran into a vault of Greater Molochs. It took me HOURS to kill just one, but once I did, my level rocketed and I was able to kill each one easier until my 100 Courage could take on 2-3 at a time, hitting lvl50 in no time. The Balors at the end nearly killed me, but I desperately used a scroll of familiar summoning and hit the jackpot -- a Greater Flame Elemental killed literally everything but me on the entire floor. I just followed it around and picked through the carnage. My second playthrough was a Wizard, Gafgarion, that died in the duel with Nuurag-Vaarn. When 1.2.0 was released, I dove in head first with a LOT of attempts, but finally got a High Elven Paladin, Matthias, and for the first time I got Justifier. For those who don't know, this may be one of the best non-minmax occurrences in the game. I edited my sprite to epic proportions, turning Justifier into the Master Sword from Zelda, and mopped through every dungeon. You think such imbalance isn't fun after while... until your save loads a JSON error and corrupts, thereby losing everything.

Now that I'm done rambling, here's what makes this Steam version special. You can remove all of what I just talked about. However, that's not such a bad thing. What the Steam release signifies is a willingness to accept new players. The depth and complexity of content in ADOM is such that I probably haven't seen half of it. And it's probably only going to get bigger. Therefore, it makes sense to have ways to let players explore it. There's still tons wrong with it, as one review brought up the online-only functionality. This doesn't really bother me. Unless he's travelling in the bush (doubtful), turn on hotspot on your phone for 5 mins. The act of getting ADOM on Steam in a saleable format was probably a Herculean task, and so I expect errors. Any aspersions against customer sales disrespect are fallacious and made by people who have clearly never perused the forums or seen comments made by Thomas Biskup. Since Morrowind modding, I have never seen such a dedicated community of collaborative effort.

It has never been a better age to get into roguelikes, and this game is one of the best. If you've been poisoned against rogues by the more recent entries in the genre, give a classic a try and see what made them great to begin with.

19221073.review:
'You find yourself in the bowels of a dank dungeon, your robes burned to ashes, bleeding from your wounds.  The dread beast that inflicted the wounds upon you lies smoldering before you, the last of your power expended upon its ruin.  Through the doorway that led you to this chamber, you hear a thunderous 'HARUMPH'.  This can only mean ruin.  You frantically search your belongings, desperate for salvation.  You pray to your God, but the ground quakes at your request, a stern denial from your patron deity.  A tremendous stomping grows nearer, and you fear that your time is short.  Sweat pouring down your bleeding face, you find a Wand of Digging in your pack, intact but depleted of charges, alongside your Wand of Door Creation.  Like a man gone mad, you plunge the Wand of Digging into your only potion of Booze, and cry out when the wand glows once more.  You fire it behind you, creating a vast tunnel wherein you dash for safety.  You zap your Wand of Door creation behind you, and with your faintly regained power Magically Lock the summoned door.  You run down your new corridor, seeking escape, only to find another dead end.  The impossibly heavy steps of the impending creature grow close now, as you huddle in the corner of your shelter.  The steps cease, you hold your breath in sheer terror, silently attempting to gather yourself in meditation and regain power.  An explosion of splinters erupts from the other side of your corridor, and the many eyed horror that approaches from the gloom freezes you in your place.  You think of Terinyo as the horror steps toward you, you think of the home you left behind.  Your fear gives way to darkness, the darkness to silence; Ancardia's greatest hope extinguished like a torch in the rain.'

You die.  You survive.  You learn. ADOM is a game that offers you a canvas upon which to design your own adventure.  Are you a hero?  A villain?  Do you aspire to seal the forces of Chaos away, or reign over it a mad God for eternity?  Are you a simple farmer, far from home?  A gambler, seeking the highest stakes casino in all the world?  Call it a roguelike, call it a fantasy role playing sandbox, call it a sadistic RNG exercise, ADOM is all that and far more.  No experience is perfect, games crash, characters are lost.  ADOM is mysterious, and you may puzzle at the Scroll of Dark Predictions in your inventory, or the Tract of Chaos you see on the ground.  You may wander to the Tower of Eternal Flames, and enter without caution.  You die.  You survive.  You learn.  ADOM is a game of mystery, a game of skill, a game of chance.  Distinct from its peers, beloved by its fanbase, and better than ever here on Steam.  Don't fear the learning curve, if you've whiled away hours exploring Morrowind, Baldur's Gate, Fallout, this game may be the gateway to a genre you've never given a thought to before, as it was for me.

19177057.review:
The early game in ADOM constantly asks you to make risk vs reward decisions. Whether to stand and fight, or run away and heal. Whether to kick down a door and risk activating a trap, or come back later with a key. Whether to risk delving one level deeper, or travel to a safer location. Making the wrong call will often lead to an early death, but negotiate these issues and your character will be set up for the challenges that follow.

For newcomers to the game, I advise choosing a stong melee character (e.g. an orc fighter), and start in the tutorial dungeon to get used to the basics of moving around and hitting things with swords. This is what you'll be doing for the majority of the time, regardless of class. You can then let the complexities of the other mechanics seep in over time.

I used to play a lot of the ASCII version, but not so much recently. I'm already impressed with the new graphical tileset and other features which are in this version, and the game underneath is still the exciting combination of exploration and danger it always was.

It's a great roguelike with many quests, large world map with many types of dungeons and  large variety of classes and races. THIS is what a godd*** roguelike is. If you like the genre, you probably already have a copy, one of the free ones. Why buy it on Steam when you can get Version 60 for free? 19141194.review:
I will start with the con (just one) in this game: The learning curve / keybindings are tough on this. You need to be patient and learn/ list lots of commands on the keyboard.


I first played ADOM around 2003-2004. We had a crappy computer which couldn't handle many games at all, but my brother had ADOM on it. I tested it and was instantly hooked: So much to explore, so hard! Only one life? The merciless roguelike system where the game is permanently over when you die made me curious.

The added graphics are quite nice addition to the game and I imagine it's easier for new players to get into the game. I use only the keyboard controls for the game, as it is much faster (and I've played it for years so it comes natural). I recommend tackling the keyboard commands if you want faster gameplay.

There are so many ways you can be good (or bad) at this game. The game has been around for decades so it is well-balanced, but also still very challenging. I haven't still finished this game without "cheating", that is what was known as save scumming, where you copy the save file in case you die and continue game from there. I died just once to a stupid mistake which I don't remember anymore, but it still annoys me, even after multiple years. I'm fully determined to finish ADOM in the near future...
In a nutshell, the reasons I enjoy playing ADOM:
- Challenging enough
- Addictive - you'll probably end up screaming like a maniac for dying, swear you had enough ADOM for a week, only to find yourself trying a new character 10 minutes later
- Variable - Dozens, if not hundreds of ways to play the game (race, class combinations + different endings, quests to pursue, places to visit)
- Unpredictable - You might get mighty lucky early in the game, or really unlucky (dying to a random stone block trap early on for example), or both at the same, or neither. Just like life!
- Bang for your buck - If you end up liking this game, you will probably enjoy it for years - I estimate that I have played more than 1000 hours pre-steam

If you decide to buy the game: Don't totally spoil yourself reading guides beforehand - just go to places, explore them and read late-game guides only if you get stuck to some place. Trust me, you will enjoy the exploration more on your own.

19137497.review:
I had to think hard about whether or not I wanted to recommend this game or not. Its one of those "two-and-a-half to three stars' moments. 

Now I have to explain that I'm one of those people who were playing ADOM since early-days. I spent countless hours and spent dozens on dozens of characters to their eventual deaths. And that is something you have to get used to in this game. Your characters die. When they die, they're gone for good. Shiny gear. Nifty abilities. Everything. Gone. The only thing you'll have to remember them by is their entry on your personal high score board reminding you that your best character died on level 5 of some hole in the field because he/she died of the black plague because you ate a kobold corpse on the ground. 

I'm resisting the urge to ramble on and on here. ADOM really is a good game! Its wonderfully complex yet simple in its premise. There is no real story involved. 'Go and fight Chaos'. They drop you on the world and wish you good luck. The overworld is always the same. And the dungeons you dive into are always random. But this time, instead of the ASCII characters representing yourself, enemies, and items on the ground, you have a nifty little graphical representation. And in the 'old' game, you had to memorize a LOT of hotkeys, as combinations of letters with alt/shift/ctrl were what you had to press to perform actions and bring up menus. 

But that's the rub. The GUI (that's Graphical User Inferface), in my opinion, is about 75% of what you're buying here. Yes, there are a few different modes you can play in. Yes, you can now play by using the mouse and right-clicking to bring up a menu of things you can do instead of remembering its keystroke to make it more forgiving for newbies learning how to get around - though the game itself can still be brutal. But when you get down to brass tacks, you're buying cosmetics. 

That's why I wavered on the tumbs up and tumbs down. I love ADOM. It's a relic from junior high through college for me. But are you willing to drop more than $10 for what adds up to little more than polish? I did, for the nostaliga. But it might be a touch stiff for others when they could have gotten the original ADOM for free in the past.

19137095.review:
My four brothers and I have been playing ADOM since about 2000. We have dedicated uncountable hours to this game, improving our talents/skill choices, learning which monsters are dangerous (nearly all of them in their own way, even as food!), how to not starve to death, how to infer properties of unidentified items, how to make your deity happy (very useful), to always eat ogre and blink dog corpses, and that you should never attempt any alchemy as an amateur no matter how innocent appearing (not even mixing water and carrot juice).

Yet not once have any of us beat the game. Some of us have gotten close a couple times, but no cigar.  Unlike the vast majority of all games, beating this game without scum saving is truly a respectable achievement and the journey itself will yield many super-intense close calls.

Despite the difficulty, we still play it and always come back to it. The ADOM world has so much depth, playing the game is really like exploring a new world.

ADOM is probably one of the best RPGs in existence. If you can look past the simple graphics and turn based play, this game will yield many, many hours of fun.

Welcome to the only world you'll ever want to live in for the foreseeable future!  Filled with an amazing and detailed story, ADOM is the true definition of Rogue-like.  But unlike many other Roguelikes that you'll find on steam, Ancient Domains of Mystery really does make you worry about losing your character, while simultaneously making you want to start again the second you die.  From exploring caves to finishing quests for unique items, ADOM has something for everyone.  And now with its new (and totally optional) UI, it even has graphics for those who can't stand nethack.

Now that it's on Steam, I am happy to spend my money to support the ADOM crew and continue to keep this jewel alive.

I highly urge users to try to the ASCII version prior to playing with the graphical version.  I say this because it will absolutely help you understand the mechanics and probabilities of this game.  I don't personally care for the graphical version, but being a fan of skyrim and fallout, I can also understand the longing for something more than ASCII characters moving around.

The world of Ancardia is so full and detailed, that it will help you immensely to look up your class and race to see what fun specialties they afford you! 19136449.review:
Don't let my hours into this game fool you. I've been playing this game exponentially longer than it has been on Steam. I think I first picked this game up in 2003, and can remember when your character was a colored @.

The graphics for this game has come a long way, and even though, compared to other games, it's own graphic detail may seem somewhat lacking, that's not the key feature here. Allow me to start likening it to other games.

In spite of the fact that it takes up about the same amount of space on your Hard Drive as Five Nights At Freddy's, it's story, lore, and gameplay are almost as deep as the land of Tamriel's. Gameplay is smooth, and the controls, while beyond numerous, are simple, and easy to understand. The downside is the difficulty. I have been playing it for years, and I have never beaten it. Namely, this is because I tend to have a Throw-Myself-At-Anything strategy, and if you are not careful, this can lead to you having a bad day really quick. Couple the fact that this game comes standard with PermaDeath, and you really want to be careful how you play. Imagine Dark Souls with the Skyrim Dead is Dead mod installed. Pretty hardcore. In addition, the game has at least six different endings. Multiple quests, endless, randomly generated dungeons, with a few of them literally infinite in size. An expansive, MASSIVE overworld that is bigger than the size of Oblivion. Random encounters in the wild with numerous creatures to face, from bandits to jackals to the Brotherhood of Chaos to hill giants. A simplistic, incredibly fun game with an incredible lore. You have multiple races, and multiple classes to pick from, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Pray to the gods for assistance, but don't abuse their generosity. And with Talents, you can customize your ratling fencer to be unique from other Ratling Fencers you may create, leading to an admittedly still finite, but very, very, VERY large pool of possible combinations. This is a game 22 years in the making, and it has managed to stay true to it's roots, while at the same time become attractive to a newer audience. I highly recommend it.

19136290.review:
As someone who has been playing ADOM since last century, I highly reccomend this game. But be warned, it is not a simple game where you will sit down for five minutes to flick birds at stuff. This game requires time and patience of you, but it gives back as much as you give.

For new players, a few tips: you have a deity, and you should pray when things get tough. Buy food if you didn't start with much, and especially have food for long treks through the wilderness. Anyone can put a madman out of his misery - a true hero will find a way to heal him. Giant inscects have hard shells, and you may need to swing like a berserker to cut through. Your first mindcrafter will be killed by a stone block; do not be angry when this happens. Until you understand how altars work, do not step on black ones.

And keep at it. Yes, you will die a lot. Expect your high scores to fill up with level 1-7 heroes before you really start to master this game. Winning this game is not an eventual certainty. It is a glorious achievement.

Axes high!

19128716.review:
[b][i]ADOM[/i] by many measures, is one of [i]the few[/i] classic roguelikes that started it all.[/b] In developement since 1994, and by reading over its history, I can say it has come a long way. This title can certainly hold its own right up  there with the best of modern games. Some may have you believe a single person (Thomas Biskup) built this, but as is stated in the credits, the end product is the result of thousands of peoples hard work and ideas. [i]Certainly Mr. Biskup deserves the lion's share of credit, but compared to other indie titles, this is hardly something that came out of someones basement over the weekend.[/i]

[i]Classic roguelikes are nearly infinite in replayability, and possibility.[/i] Sure, there is a certain trade-off between user interface, graphics, and learning curve that pays out with a giant world with metric tons of gameplay and fun. [b]Yes, its difficult. Yes, you will need to read lots (thank you in-game manual). Yes, it is FUN.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Timeless game that has been shaped over 20 years, which is reflected by system complexity that goes unmatched in modern games.
+The ability to seemlessly (simply push F10) switch between classic ASCII and tiles.
+Tiles and music are beautifully done.
+Many modes that are all well recieved. In example, Crowd mode alters the difficulty of your game by how many Steam friends you have that play [i]ADOM[/i]. This is fresh and certainly encourages community.
+++Highscores leaderboards!
+++Ghosts of your fallen Steam friends show up in your game lol.
+Both keyboard and mouse support. I find the control scheme very intuitive. The updated user interface is very nice IMO.
+In-depth tutorial.
+Great community.
+Super active developement.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Yeah there is a steep learning curve, but that only applies to people that are new to roguelikes. Get through it, or simply realize these types of games are not your cup of tea.

[b]If you have any interest in PC gaming history at all, this title deserves to be in your library. What a gem.[/b] It amazes me how this classic has evolved over time and can still outcompete modern titles.

19126113.review:
I *love* this game. I've been playing for almost 20 years and I'm still not bored of it. Massively recommended classic roguelike, now with prettified graphics and sound.

HOWEVER, you should be aware of a few things before you buy:
 - Turn-based (Roguelike)
 - Steep learning curve, including Permadeath (Roguelike)
 - Tile graphics covering up an ASCII system (Roguelike)
 - Somewhat archaic control system (but the best amongst the classic Roguelikes IMO, with decent inventory control)
 - Awkward to play without a numpad - especially if you don't have an actual mouse. Not recommended for any but the biggest laptop keyboards.
 - Just in case it wasn't really obvious, this is very much a thinking gamer's game. It has ZERO twitch.

And probably the worst point:
 - Many new releases thusfar have included a fatal crash bug... although these are generally fixed in about 24 hours.

BUT...
If you're willing to persevere through this, you've got a game of almost unparalleled depth and enjoyment. SO much to learn, SO many different viable strategies, SO many different character builds, and SO much tension and excitement in a turn-based game.

TWENTY. YEARS.

Not bored.

Still reading? Get it.

Gamebreaking bug.  When I select my character by clicking him, the menu won't pop up, and I will be stuck.  Have to hard reset the game to restart the game. Game is probably slightly overpriced, and worth probably in the 9.99 for the basic overall quality of the game (there really is no soundtrack for example).

What is cool, is you get to play a combo of tons of races and classes (that should be more previlent in more fantasy genre games like this one), but are not.  For instance I love playing a Troll Barbarian.

This game I guess is a bit old there are some indie strat guides out there to help you select your character and to explain stuff (like selling stuff requires you to go into the merchant shop and drop the item on the shop floor, lol weird), and in that regard, the game seems overall unpolished compared to the price point which it is at imo.

----

After playing more hours and seeing the dev reply to the game, let me expand my review some more.

This is the typical game that falls into "challenging" and tries to prey on perhaps the nostalgic feelings of those who maybe played this game in the past.

Granted I like challenging games, but realistically you will get 3-7 hours of frustrating fun.

I found it extremely difficult to get past the southern dungeon on my way past the map.  

All dungeon maps are always rectangular in nature, vary very little; granted they seem to be using a random seed of some kind, but after 3-4 times it gets stale.  There are torches on the wall, other than that, there is no decor.  Character animations are limited and are only left face and right face.  Also when I equip certain equipment like the helm it is barely visible or not visible at all.

There is no soundtrack, the ambience sound is almost non-existent.  Occasionally I hear the drop of into a puddle in a dungeon.  Again, the atmosphere of the game feels incomplete.

There are TONS of games similar to this, Gauntlet $19.99 (when not on sale, 2015 game) (http://store.steampowered.com/app/258970/ ) is a popular game my friends play that has a multiplayer aspect, which this game does not have.  Also Hammerwatch $9.99 (not on sale) which does exist, unlike what the Dev has said and exists here on Steam:  http://store.steampowered.com/app/239070/


Let me describe a small experience I had playing a Troll Barbarian, which granted is pretty cool since most games fall short of providing the race/class combo which games like this should have (orignally stated above).  I roll this toon, spec into two handed weapons, and I go into the trial dungeon, first door is locked, I can only kick it down, in the process of kicking the door down my huge club is broke, lol wtf ok.  So basically your skill that you used to get the 2hed item is worthless and now you have to punch guys.
Overall sound effects are stale, limited, and lackluster, and could be improved dramatically.
If you are going to bring back a game from 1995 update date, improve it a ton.  Check out Divinity Original Sin (http://store.steampowered.com/app/373420/), a game which was just enhanced w/ over 90+ hours of gameplay and fully AAA voiced acted.
Spell casters feel bulky and there is not hotkey menu like modern games have (again you are paying for a 1995 1st addition D&D type game).  I have to constantly hit he escape menu to break away from the immersion of the game to open a spellbook.  After some casting of the spells they are "forgotton" (no tutorial on this at all btw, to explain this to first time players of ADOM like myself), and I have to relearn them.  Which means you have to worry about carrying 100 stone tombs everywhere you go.  This is a problem if you play a gnome mage (which I tried out), and tried carrying around 5 tombs plus heavy rations.
Certain classes have to eat CONSTANTLY like the game should be renamed “iron ration buffet” as trolls have to eat 1-2 every dungeon level.  Since food weighs a TON certain races are bogged down w/ carrying capacity issues (which only mildly exists as a nuisance in other games).

On the flip side I like rolling a quick character and just smashing through enemies in the dungeons.  But other games have this pleasure of smashing AI units into the ground.
Also initial encounters past the first town can kill you very easily.  You see the theme here?  This game has a HUGE learning curve w/ 8bit graphics.  Time/reward/money do not align that well.

Why are the rations so heavy in this game? And not proportion to the character size, again another design flaw.

This game is geared towards probably ppl who are in the 30s.  Why pay for this game when you can get far superior games for roughly 1-2x the price.  Although if you want to step into a time machine and try to play and relive the sweet memories when you were 8 years old on your Commodore.

I feel like this game is a semi money grab at the nostalgic feels of old time gamers who played this game and who want to shell out $ for these feels.

After being frustrated for the last time, I uninstalled.

Funny, when a long time bud on Steam who saw me playing this game on messaged me:

"2015 >> azbolg still playing shit games"

This game is a solid 4 / 10.

19125221.review:
0.) Warning! This review mentions several things that may or may not be spoilers. The game is randomized to a degree and also depends greatly on your own choices in-game. There is no right or wrong way to play, but I do mention several things that I consider to be entertaining examples of ADOM's charm. Everything below is optional and nothing below is related to the "main plot" but if the threat of spoilers gives you heart palpitations, just know that I heartily endorse ADOM (whether in ASCII or in the new graphical mode). It's one of my top 10 games of all-time, and I gladly supported it during its indiegogo campaign despite there still being a completely free version available from the developer. It's just that good.

1.) This game has entertained me for well over a decade, and I'm still not tired of it.

2.) Every time you start a new character, make a note of what your first kill is; trust me.

3.) Don't kick a door head-on if you can help it; diagonals are best.

4.) Killing cats is bad.

5.) If you find yourself with a cursed item, you might want to try stripping naked and standing in an acid trap for a few minutes.

6.) Don't touch strange trees you find underground.

7.) Never sell or drop your last Si.

8.) If at first you don't succeed, try playing a hurthling archer.

9.) There is a dedicated hotkey for wiping your face, and you'll need it.

10.) After 1000+ hours, I have never managed to reach even one of the possible endings; the furthest I've reached is character level 43 and it was glorious.

19123516.review:
Hah. How to review ADOM? Well, it's one of the Great Few, an actual roguelike (not roguelikelike or light or anything) that helped define the genre. ADOM's strongest points are a mix of a persistent plot with procedurally generated elements, and a much deeper lore than its kin.

Once again the ultimate evil raises its ugly head and only a single hero can defeat it because fate says so. That hero is you. Or, will be you. Eventually you will defeat evil. But before that, you will die. A lot. And then again, and then some more. And you'll probably love every single death because you learned something, or had the chance to try out a new trick, or just had a brief moment of clarity how something COULD be done, only you didn't do it.

ADOM "Steam" is a pretty huge package. While the original game can be played for free, this version comes with a nice set of "deluxe" options and, seriously, this is a game that has been around for ages. I played it for ages. I think it's fair that at some point someone gets a bit of my money for the entertainment I had, because this is a game made for old dogs like me. A perfect throwback to my teen years, not pimped out until it's no longer the game I learned to love but with a nice, sensible lick of paint and a sleek interface. And I can still have it all in ASCII if I want.

There's just no way not to recommend this game. 
If you already know it, you want to buy it for the same reasons I did: For nostalgia, for running the dungeons again, for feeling the thrill of a fight where each move matters, for smiling at the fact that your Steam Playtime can never, ever, match the hours you already sunk into this monster.
If you never heard of ADOM, you want to try it out because it is a nicely structured, engrossing game that polishes some concepts of the genre to a silky sheen. You'll appreciate the interface, which is readable but doesn't get in your way, you'll start out small and then you'll be hooked.

All this said, it's still a roguelike. As in, one of the games that took care we HAVE roguelikes. There are many things here that are part of the genre but not to everyone's taste- a fairly rocky early game, permadeath, TONS of ways to die yeat another stupid death, and an omnipresent element of randomness that can, and will, screw you up big time at least once per run. ADOM doesn't pull any punches and you need to be aware of that, this is not a recent rogue-light, this is bedrock. If you are just curious what the craze is all about, you may want to try the free version, just to see how it sits with you. 

Because like most old roguelikes, ADOM is a game that rewards patience, planning, developing strategies and preparing for the worst- while still allowing players to improvise and come out of a tight spot with some sweet experience and a new trick in their book. 

15 Euros can buy you more recent, visually impressive, or (to be honest) more streamlined games after all, but ADOM takes time to master, and beating it once is nothing, considering the endless replayability the genre itself has to offer.

Happy dungeon-dwelling, spell-singing and corpse-cursing!

19120946.review:
I've been waiting years for a way to pay the author for creating ADOM, which I view as the finest procedurally driven RPG ever created. 

ADOM is a game in the tradition of rogue, hack, and nethack. To describe it as "hard" would be both true and misleading: It's actually very easy to play and very easy to make a lot of progress, but actually winning is a delicate and unlikely affair. Dying is practically inevitable and although in the "Deluxe" version it's possible to turn off perma-death it's certainly not in the spirit of the game to do so. I can't even begin to enumerate the number of games I've played but I've saved well over a hundred memorials to "notable" dead characters on this computer alone. I have only approached the approximate half-way point twice, I have never come close to winning... and still I play, because what keeps me coming back is the variety and the challenge.

This is not a game you will win in a weekend, or a month, or a year, but you will enjoy every session (right up to the moment you die). I encourage you, dear reader, to cough up the meager sum that is asked here for this gem and immerse yourself in a wonderful game in which the developer has truly Thought Of Everything. If mud splashes on your face it blinds you until you wipe it away. If it's dark or you're illiterate you can't read books or scrolls; if you're deaf you can't hear what NPCs say to you, but the wail of a banshee will also not affect you. Sometimes kicking things breaks them, sometimes it just hurts your leg. You can eat the raw corpse of a hurthling but it will taste better and sustain you longer if you cook it first.  The texture and depth is incredible and, thanks to randomly generated elements, your choice of race, class and winning strategy it's never quite the same twice.

For new players I recommend three things: Patience, determination, and to avoid standing directly in front of doors when opening them. Your reward: endless fun.

19119404.review:
The first RPG I've played, and one I still come back to every now and then. I've been excited ever since the crowdfunding campaing, and been singing praises of this game ever since. It's brutal, hard and random, yes, but such is the nature of TRUE rogue-likes. 

Deluxe version gives you the options to lower the difficulty for more casual of players, so they can get enjoyment out of this game as well. Even giving you option to properly save your game, unlike the normal mode, where your game save is tied to your characters life, once character dies, it's gone. This is something not available in the free version. More on that later.

But the true meat of this game comes from flexibility of the combat... You have your basic Melee, Ranged and Magic attacks, but you also can use Mindcraft, companions, special race/class abilities and alchemy to name a few varied methods of dealing damage. But you can in turn take damage from ridiculous stuff among others, and get killed in many, many ways, including getting crushed by dungeon, whipping yourself to death, getting sacrificed to one of many gods, having too much stuff in your inventory and my personal favorite: Getting eaten by grue. Also, you can get killed before you even move (or take your first step) with certain race/class combinations on certain day.

There are plenty of static elements in game that stay same from game to game, but majority of the dungeons are randomly generated, keeping you on your toes every time. No two games are the same, which makes this game highly replayable.

Deluxe version of ADOM is not only worth your money, but as it gets more features, which will keep coming until the Creator of this game feels this game is complete (and moves onto the Sequel) makes this game truly worthwhile. But if you are not certain of getting the Deluxe version yet, you can always download the Free version of this game from ADOM homepage, and try it out as much you want. The base game is the same regardless, but There are bunch of nifty features that will not be in the free versions ever. But if you so desire, you can run the newest free version of this game on your Amiga or old MS-Dos computers. That's how old-school this game is.

//Additions
- Point based Character creation has been Added to the game, which allows more customization.
- You can now also Choose your starting Starsign, unlike previously
- Majority of Bugs Fixed (Basically, unless you applied to the beta, which you can do if you so desire, you shouldn't encounter any bugs)

//Coming Features
- Animations
- Volcano (A new dungeon, that is completely different from other places currently in game)
- More Quests
- Even more Bugfixes

You will encounter mind boggling scenarios and unimaginable deaths. For instance, I was walking through a dungeon once and I heard a water trap go off. I came around a corner and I was blown to bits by fiery death. As I sat there wondering what in the hell just happened, I came to realize that a goblin had stepped on the water trap that I had heard go off and when he got hit with the water, a potion that he was carrying reacted with the water and exploded. 19119284.review:
(TL:DR: great game and it is a finished game but it is not ready for a general steam audience)

I'm putting this as a positive review because I think ADOM is a great game which is lots of fun but there are lots of warnings I have to give to people who haven't played this game or old school roguelikes before.

(I came back to this review and really wanted to tone the review down because I think the dev is a great guy and it's a really fun game but I have to be honest: there are a lot of pretty big annoyances that will make people not used to the game regret buying it, and people do need to realize that development, while always ongoing, is not as rapid as some other games, and patience is required).


The game was greenlit a long time ago and wasn't released on steam until a year and a half later. The explanation for this was polishing the game for the general steam audience rather than the more forgiving hardcore old fans of the game. Despite this, it is not really ready for a general audience despite there being easily enough time to prepare it.

[strike]1. The game can crash: I experienced a crash within my first two hours of play. The game is permadeath but does autosave every 1000 turns. The problem is that in order to recover from a crash you have to know what you are doing and rename a certain file a certain way. The game is not programmed to realize it hasn't shut down cleanly so it can't help you.[/strike]seems fixed

2. There is mouse control but it's not total, meaning you have to press keys sometimes. It's not easy to even predict when you'll have to press a key rather than being able to use the mouse.

3. The default keys are really bad from a HCI point of view (human-computer interaction): For example to rest to regain hp etc. until something disturbs you is w5 or w. That's a two key sequence for something you will be doing all the time. [strike]Even worse is the autoexplore which is w?. That's a two key sequence with the second key requiring shift! This for something you will also be doing constantly. [/strike]auto-explore is now - (minus) (casting spells as shift z, (pick spell letter), direction is bad too although is being changed to non shifted z which is slightly better)

4. It is possible to redefine the keys but unless you are an old player of adom or go looking on forums you wouldn't know how to. You have to go and get the config key file from where the game saves game data to (as in not the base game directory, e.g. for me it's C:\Users\<username>\Documents\ADOM\adom_steam) edit it in a text editor (and you have to know how to) [strike]and then put it in the right directory.[/strike]

5. There are certain features "coming soon". They include things like points-based character creation and being able to choose your star sign. Despite these things really not taking very long at all to program, they have been languishing on todo lists for ages. One of these at least was used by the greenlight campaign as an example of something that would be exclusive to the steam version and yet somehow didn't get programmed in the year and a half between being greenlit and steam release. (It's a couple of hours' work at the most).

19118703.review:
ADOM is the definitive rogue-like experience. If you're a fan of rogue-likes, you've probably played ADOM already. However, this is the first of the classic rogue-likes to make its way into Steam and a wide new audience. People who are interested in rogue-like themes and the so called rogue-lite games might find a lot to like here.

As a rogue-like, ADOM is a turn-based RPG. This means that every time you take an action, all of the other characters in the game do so as well, including enemies. In a sense, it's not really turn-based as all the movement happens at once, meaning you never have to wait for the enemy's movement. Combat is a simple matter at ground level but gets more complex as the game progresses. In its most basic form, you are simply "running" into enemies. This causes you to attack them and they will attack back at you and so on. However, you can influence this combat in many ways. This includes switching your tactics to gain better to-hit chance and damage at the expense of defenses (can be used flexibly and in different ways depending on the situation), casting spells, drinking potions, zapping wands, reading scrolls, firing missiles, using skills and maneuvering around the dungeon to name a few. Trash mobs you can simply run into and destroy with ease, but whenever you encounter a new and unknown, potentially strong monster, you might want to slow down the pace and consider what gear you have to help you. And remember the number one rule of rogue-likes: always have an escape plan in mind!

ADOM is absolutely brutal. Rogue-lite games often mention how they are extremely difficult and will require multiple tries before you beat them. These games also tend to be relatively short, 1-2 hour experiences in various genres from fps to platformers. ADOM on the other hand is a purebred rogue-like through and through; a successful game is likely to take 15+ hours and the hundreds of failures you will suffer on the way will add even more hours on top of that. Now I happen to think this is a strength; there is immense amounts of replayability in the game due to a variety of races and classes you can play as, in addition to a huge amount of procedural generation when it comes to monsters you encounter, loot you find and dungeon layouts you will explore. And once you beat the game normally, guess what! There's several Ultra Endings to attempt as well! These endings are insanely hard to pull off, require EVEN more tries than the normal one and are virtually impossible without some outside information sources.

ADOM's strength in relation to other rogue-likes lies in its structured nature: Terinyo is always in the same place as well as the main dungeons of the game. There are quests that you will undertake in a logical order and once you learn your way around the early game, it is possible to form a strategy. This is absolutely key; where many rogue-likes hinge purely on RNG to get you going, ADOM actually has a very deep strategy layer to its gameplay. The other notable selling point in relation to other rogue-likes is the skill system; every race and class has a set of skills they start off with, and these skills can be improved as you advance in levels. This gives leveling a more meaningful feeling compared to some other rogue-likes where you simply gain more health and magic points.

Now this review could go on forever, but hopefully I've given you some insight into whether or not ADOM is something you might be into. Personally, I love this game. I have beaten it three times the normal way and once I've achieved the Avatar of Order ending. I've played this game over the course of 15 years, two development cycles and who knows how many hours. It is truly something special.

Lastly, some meta-advice:

-Do not play the game in softcore mode! Permadeath is an integral part of the rogue-like experience and you will hate ADOM if you don't have permadeath on. A character is very likely to die; you have to learn to deal with it. The entire premise of the game is that you roll hundreds of characters until finally one of them sticks and gets farther into the game than the others. If you keep struggling with a character who was never even meant to survive the experience will be miserable. Not to mention you will never have that feeling of utter disaster when your best character dies at the final level. Or on the way back after winning the game. And all of those losses will build up to the final success; when you finally, after all that heartbreak, beat the game and leave Drakalor Chain, you look back at the time you've spent and go: "Fuck yes, I actually did it. I beat this son of a bitch of a game. Hell yes."

-Don't be afraid to look up stuff on the wiki: ADOM is a massive game and very cryptic in some areas. However, I would suggest avoiding making a habit out of this. Explore the game freely; you're going to die so many times anyway so what's the point of completely spoiling yourself? But once you get a promising character rolling, you might want to check up on the effects of eating this specific monster's corpse, or how dangerous exactly that Gorgon is ;)

-Give the ASCII version a try! The tilesets are very nicely done and the bare-bones ASCII style might seem clunky and unintuitive at first. But you'd be surprised at the advantages it has. For example, you will easily identify new enemies: a small "g" is always going to be a goblin-like small humanoid, an uppercase "D" is always going to be a dragon or dragon-like huge lizard like drake and so on. Very clear and handy compared to the tilesets imo. Not to mention the ASCII graphics are just so damn charming!

-vesmo

19118618.review:
Many games these days boast to have vast open worlds, open-ended gameplay and endless replayability - ADOM actually delivers.

- Background -

I first played ADOM in 2003. I've since spent hundreds of hours exploring the mysterious Drakalor Chain. ADOM is one of my all-time favourite games, and certainly the only game originally released in the 90's that I don't play for nostalgia - but because it is still fresh.

ADOM is an RPG in the true sense of the word: it does not impose restrictions on you. The problem I have with most RPGs these days is how they limit the player's actions. The choice between good and evil is often in fact the choice between the good and evil dialogue option. ADOM is different in that you can actually do whatever you want, be anyone you want to be. And doing whatever you want actually means something in ADOM, since the game has a ridiculously large amount of content. Really, it does.

- Gameplay -

In ADOM, first you'll create your character. Your character will be given a starsign that will have some effect on him/her. After that you'll choose your race, profession, talents etc. from a ton of options. These choises will guide you as you start your journey, but won't limit you as (or if) you progress.

As the game begins, you enter Drakalor Chain, a troubled valley with many mysteries to explore. From then on it's all up to you. Go to the nearest village and interact with the townsfolk or find your own path. Battle fierce beasts, learn incredible spells, rob stores, fight for money, make friends, embark on quests, search for artifacts, brew deadly poisons, control minds, barter items, cook food, worship your gods, play instruments, raise the dead, clean your ears...

And of course you'll die. You'll be drowned, burnt and crushed to death. You'll die of hunger and sickness and bloodloss. You'll accidentally kill yourself conducting dangerous magical experiments. You'll die as you are sacrificed to strange and terrible gods. You'll die and return. And maybe, just maybe you'll one day defeat the powers that plague Drakalor Chain. I never did, yet, but I'll keep on trying.

See you in the Caverns of Chaos!
